(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1974
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce that the October 1974 Term of the
Supreme Court of the United States is now convened."
ADMISSIONS OF ATTORNEYS DURING THE SUMMER RECESS
The following attorneys were admitted to the Bar of this Court by
action of single Justices during the summer recess, pursuant to the
Order of this Court entered on the twenty-fourth day of May, 1971:
ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON WRITTEN MOTIONS

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1974
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
19
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 74-165. Robert W. Blanchette et al., as Trustees of the Prop-
erty of Penn Central Transportation Company, appellants, v. Con-
necticut General Insurance Corporation et al.;
No. 74-166. Richard Joyce Smith, Trustee of the Property of the
New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, appellant,
v. United States et al.;
No. 74-167. United States Railway Association, appellant, v. Con-
necticut General Insurance Corporation et al.; and
No. 74-168. United States et al., appellants, v. Connecticut Gen-
eral Insurance Corporation et al. Appeals from the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Motion of
Brock Adams et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted.
Motion of The National Industrial Traffic League for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, granted. In these cases probable jurisdiction
noted. Cases consolidated and a total of three hours allotted for oral
argument. Motion to expedite granted and cases set for oral argument
on Wednesday, October 23, 1974.
580-278-74—3

(JOURNAL) FRIDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1974
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
21
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-232. Minnesota et al., applicants, v. Reserve Mining Co.
et al.; and
No. A-262. United States, applicant, v. Reserve Mining Co. et al.
The applications for an order vacating or modifying the stay order
of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court,
are denied. Four Justices, however, state explicitly that these denials
are without prejudice to the applicants' renewal of their applications
to vacate if the litigation has not been finally decided by the Court
of Appeals by January 31, 1975. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. A-256. John Hill, Attorney General of Texas et al., appli-
cants, v. Printing Industries of the Gulf Coast et al. The application
for stay of judgment of the United States District Court for the South-
ern District of Texas presented to Mr. Justice Powell, and by him
referred to the Court, is granted pending the timely docketing of an
appeal and final disposition thereon. Mr. Justice Douglas would
deny the application.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1974
23
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice.
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1370. Anna A. Phelps, appellant, v. Robert D. Morgan,
District Judge, United States District Court for the Southern District
of Illinois, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73-1615. Marcus Morales Calderon, appellant, v. Board of
Education of the El Monte School District of Los Angeles County.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73–1729. Carl A. Johnson, appellant, v. Laramie County
School District No. 1. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wyoming.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 73-1817. Philip R. Brothers, etc., appellant, v. California.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73-1928. Public Utility District No. 1 of Douglas County,
Washington, et al., appellants, v. Blaine M. Madden et al. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73–1965. Grady Lee Shepherd, appellant, v. Arkansas. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal is dismissed

for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

Appeal from the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of the
California, County of Alameda. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for certiorari, certiorari is denied.

whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-

Government et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-

for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73-6965. Arthur Falkner and Syble June Falkner, appellants,
v. David Goodhart et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-

No. 74-43. E. Dennis Barnes, appellant, v. Lewis S. Bell et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Wyandot County. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 73–1400. Upper Missouri River Corporation, appellant, v.
Board of Review, Woodbury County, Iowa. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Iowa. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
No. 73-6933. Delbart Duchein, appellant, v. Mayor of the City
of New York et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for
oral argument.
No. 73–7096. Michael A. Epps et al., appellants, v. Maryland.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas
would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 73–1495. Francis J. Cahill et al., appellants, v. Cedar
County, Iowa, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Iowa. Judgment affirmed.

No. 73-1669. Congress of Railway Unions, appellant, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the District of Columbia with direc-
tions to dismiss case as moot.
No. 73-1758. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Edu-
cation and Welfare, appellant, v. John A. Jobst. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri.
Motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Western District of Missouri for reconsideration in light
of 42 U.S.C. (Supp. II, 1972) 1381 et seq. (86 Stat 1329; Pub. L. No.
92-603 (Oct. 30, 1972)).
No. 73-1831. Scott Paper Company and International Paper Com-
pany, appellants, v. United States et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this appeal.
No. 73-1998. Herman L. Driskell et al., appellants, v. Edwin W.
Edwards, Governor of Louisiana, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Western District of Louisiana. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Western District of Louisiana with directions to enter a fresh decree
from which a timely appeal may be taken to the Court of Appeals.
See Wilson v. City of Port Lavaca, 391 U.S. 352 (1968).
No. 73-6693. Miguel A. Gargallo, appellant, v. Presiding Judge,
Franklin County Common Pleas Court, etc., et al. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin County. Motion to defer con-
sideration denied. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1392. Random House, Inc., petitioner, v. Max Gordon. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. Motion of Association of American Publishers,
Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of
Philadelphia Newspapers, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further con-

28
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1974
sideration in light of Gertz v. Robert Welch, Inc., 418 U.S.
(1974). Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 73–1926. Housing Authority of Louisville et al., petitioners,
v. Mary Fletcher, etc.; and
No. 73–1934. Department of Housing and Urban Development
et al., petitioners, v. Mary Fletcher, etc. On petitions for writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petitions for writs of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and cases
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of Pub. L. No. 93-383 (August 22, 1974).
No. 73–1972. Joseph G. Cannon, Warden, et al., petitioners, v.
Charles Thomas and Luther W. Miller. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated
and case remanded to Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of Wolff v. McDonnell, 418 U.S. (pages 31-32 of slip
opinion) (1974).
-
No. 73–6255. Walter Edward Terrell, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings, including re-entry of its judgment affirming petitioner's con-
viction and consideration of the appointment of counsel for petitioner
in connection with seeking review in this Court of the judgment of
the Court of Appeals. Schreiner v. United States, 404 U.S. 67 (1971).
No. 73-6349. Frank Alfred Analla, Jr., petitioner, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon the repre-
sentation of the Solicitor General set forth in his brief for the United
States filed July 26, 1974, judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of the position
presently asserted by the government.

docket and to dismiss the appeal pursuant to Rule 14(3) of the Rules

No. A-151. Jane Doe, individually, and on behalf of all others
similarly situated, applicant, v. Edwin F. Mundy, individually and

et al. The application for a stay presented to Mr. Justice White, and

Howard Callaway, Secretary of the Army. et al. The application for
an extension of the temporary restraining order and for reduction
of bond presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to
the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant the appli-
cation pending timely filing and disposition of a petition for a writ
of certiorari.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. The Report of the Special Master is received and or-
dered filed. Exceptions, if any, with supporting briefs to the Report
may be filed by the parties within 45 days. Reply brief, if any, to such
exceptions may be filed within 30 days. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 31, Original. State of Utah, plaintiff, v. United States. The ex-
ceptions to the Report of the Special Master are set for oral argu-
ment in due course. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this order.
No. 35, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Maine et al.
The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed. Excep-
tions, if any, with supporting briefs to the Report may be filed by the
parties within 45 days. Reply briefs, if any, to such exceptions may be
filed within 30 days.
No. 48, Original. State of Mississippi, plaintiff, v. State of
Arkanas. The parties are directed to submit a proposed amended de-
cree which has the approval of the Special Master.
No. 52, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Florida. The exceptions to the Report of the Special Master are set
for oral argument in due course.

Maine. The motion of The New Hampshire Commercial Fishermen's
Association et al., for leave to intervene is referred to the Special
Master.

Edward B. Marks Music Corporation;
No. 73–6935. Marcel Youakim et al., appellants, v. Jerome Miller,
Individually and as Director of the Department of Children and
Family Services, et al.; and
No. 74-54. Transamerican Freight Lines, Inc., petitioner, v. Brada
Miller Freight Systems, Inc., et al. The Solicitor General is invited
to file briefs in these cases expressing the views of the United States.
No. 73-5677. Maurice Schick, petitioner, v. George J. Reed, Chair-
man of the United States Board of Parole, et al. The motion of Robert
N. Sayler to permit Homer E. Moyer, Jr., Esquire to argue pro hac
vice on behalf of petitioner is granted.
No. 73–6033. Sharon Roe et al., appellants, v. Nicholas Norton, etc.
The motion of American Academy of Child Psychiatry et al., for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 74-339. Benson A. Wolman et al., appellants, v. Martin W.
Essex et al. The application for an injunction presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas would grant the injunction to enjoin Ohio's state aid to
parochial schools. See Marburger v. Public Funds for Public Schools
of New Jersey,
94 Sup. Ct. 3163 (1974). Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun would
grant the application.
U.S.
,

580-278-74--11

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1974
103
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice.
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
PER CURIAM OPINION
No. 73–1737. United States, appellant, v. Michigan National Cor-
poration et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Michigan. Judgment vacated and case remanded
for the entry of further orders in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 73-1371. New York State, on behalf of New York, Bronx and
Kings Counties, Political Subdivisions of said State, appellant, v.
United States et al.; and
No. 73-1740. New York State, on behalf of New York, Bronx and
Kings Counties, Political Subdivisions of said State, appellant, v.
United States et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for
the District of Columbia. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74–183. Alfred N. Koplin and Jean Koplin, etc., et al., appel-
lants, v. The Village of Hinsdale et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 74–194. R. C. Wall et al., appellants, v. H. D. Hardwick et al.;
and
No. 74–196. H. D. Hardwick et al., appellants, v. R. C. Wall et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Georgia. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-1612. Urban B. Luetkemeyer et al., appellants, v. Harold
Kaufmann et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Western District of Missouri. Judgment affirmed. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 73-1718. Franchise Tax Board of the State of California
et al., appellants, v. United Americans for Public Schools et al.
580-278-74-12

104
MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1974
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of California. Judgment affirmed. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice White with whom the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join.
No. 73-7028. David Bulgren, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 74-143. Lindley M. Camp et al., appellants, v. J. Ed Straughn,
Director of Department of Revenue, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 74-148. Southern Haulers, Inc., appellant, v. Department of
Public Safety et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-192. City of Virginia, Minnesota, et al., appellants, v.
George W. Nyberg et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice
White would postpone the question of jurisdiction to a hearing of the
case on the merits.
No. 74-377. Martha Kanapaux, appellant, v. James Ellisor, Direc-
tor, South Carolina State Election Commission, et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina.
Motion of John C. West et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae,
granted. Motion of Charles D. Ravenel for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae granted. Judgment affirmed.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-2047. Thomas Buck et al., petitioners, v. Impeach Nixon
Committee and Lynne Heidt. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals to ascertain whether a case or controversy still
exists and, if so, for reconsideration in light of Lehman v. City of
Shaker Heights, - U.S. — (1974).
No. 73–6795. Kenneth Kermit Hayles, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon the repre-
sentation of the Solicitor General set forth in his brief for the United
States filed September 19, 1974, judgment vacated and case remanded

15
MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1974
105
to the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas
to permit the government to dismiss the charges against the petitioner.
The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 73–296. Lawrence S. Huffman, etc., et al., appellants, v. Pursue,
Ltd. The brief for appellants does not comply with Rules 39 and 40
of the Court with respect to conciseness, the statement of questions
without unnecessary detail, and the printing of appendices thereto.
Accordingly, as provided in paragraph 5 of Rule 40, the brief of the
appellants is hereby stricken. Counsel for appellants may file a brief
complying with the Rules within 20 days of the date of this order.
Oral argument will be allowed only by counsel who have filed briefs
that conform to the Rules. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
No. 73-1004. Southeastern Promotions, Ltd., petitioner, v. Steve
Conrad et al. The motion of Charles H. Keating, Jr., for leave to file
a brief,
as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 74-1446. Joan Roe, Peter Poe and Coe Press, Inc., petitioners,
v. Jane Doe. The motion of the American Civil Liberties Union et al.
for leace to file a brief, as amici curiae, is denied. The motion of the
Association of American Publishers, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of the American Psychiatric
Association et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 73-6033. Sharon Roe et al., appellants, v. Nicholas Norton, etc.
The motion of children of appellants for divided argument with
appellants and for additional time for oral argument is granted, and
ten additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. The appellee.
allotted ten additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 74–167. United States Railway Association, appellant, v. Con-
necticut General Insurance Corporation et al. The motion of the
Trustees of the Reading Company for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, is granted.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 73–1461. Thelma B. Stanton, appellant, v. James Lawrence
Stanton, Jr. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Utah. In this case
probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 73-1933. United States, appellant, v. Citizens and Southern
National Bank et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Georgia. In this case probable jurisdic-
tion noted.
No. 73-6587. Clifford Herring, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York,

106
MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1974
Second Judicial Department. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 73–6739. Steven Costarelli, appellant, v. Massachusetts. Ap-
peal from the Municipal Court of City of Boston, Massachusetts.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case
further consideration of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to
hearing of the case on the merits.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73-1531. Albert Johnson et al., petitioners, v. Mississippi et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 74-8. J. B. O'Connor, petitioner, c. Kenneth Donaldson. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 73-1994. Julian Vella, petitioner, v. Ford Motor Company.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit granted limited to Question 1 presented by the
petition which reads as follows:
"1. Is a disabled seaman who contracted by trauma a permanent
disease while in the service of a vessel entitled to maintenance and cure
payments during the interim between the period the incident occurred.
and the time the disease was medically diagnosed and proclaimed
incurable?"
No. 73-1995. Allen F. Breed, etc., petitioner, v. Gary Steven Jones.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 73-2055. Securities Investor Protection Corporation, peti-
tioner, v. James C. Barbour et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted limited
to the following questions:
1. Whether customers of a Member have an implied private right
of action to compel SIPC to meet its alleged obligations to them under
the Act, despite Section 7(b) thereof which grants that right only to
the Securities and Exchange Commission?
2. If such a right of action can be implied, whether a receiver of
a Member has standing to maintain it?
No. 73–6650. Richard Brown, petitioner, v. Illinois. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Illinois granted.
No. 74–107. Peter Preiser, etc., et al., petitioners, v. James New-
kirk. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and

MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1974
107
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit granted. In addition to the questions presented
by the petition the parties are directed to brief and argue the question
of mootness.
No. 74–175. J. William Middendorf, II, et al., petitioners, v. Daniel
Edward Henry et al.; and
No. 74–5176. Daniel Edward Henry et al., petitioners, v. J. Wil-
liam Middendorf, II, individually and in his capacity as Secretary of
the Navy, et al. Motion of petitioner in No. 74-5176 for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted,
cases consolidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument.

No. 73–1191. Joseph M. Hourihan, petitioner, v. Harold Dakin

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit during the week of Novem-
ber 18, 1974; and for such additional time in advance thereof to
prepare for the trial of cases, or thereafter as may be required to
complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is or-
dered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, October 29, 1974, until
Monday, November 11, 1974.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73–477. Richard E. Gerstein, State Attorney for Eleventh
Judicial Circuit of Florida, petitioner, v. Robert Pugh et al. One and
one half hours allowed for reargument. Reargued by Mr. Paul L.
Friedman for the United States, as amicus curiae, by special leave of

Marky for the State of Florida, as amicus curiae, by special leave of

Lasky for the petitioners.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1974
125
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURLAM
No. 73-1791. United States, appellant, v. American Friends
Service Committee et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Judgment reversed, insofar
as it enjoins the collection of taxes by the Government and the with-
holding of wages by the employer, and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1870. James L. Huffman, appellant, v. Montana Supreme
Court et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Montana. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-32. Tomasa Vallis et al., appellants, v. Louis J. Lefkowitz,
Attorney General of the State of New York, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.
Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-1902. National Independent Coal Operator's Association
et al., appellants, v. Peter J. Brennan, Secretary of Labor. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 73–2029. Al Star et al., appellants, v. David Preller et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Maryland. Judgment affirmed. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 73-6968. Richard H. Englefield, appellant, v. Marilyn L.
Englefield. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is
580-278-74-17

126
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1974
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-37. Town of East Haven et al., appellants, v. United States
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-5145. Marian Virginia Buxton, appellant, v. Board of
Directors and Occupant of Apartment 108, etc., et al. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon.
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-6732. Samuel H. Sloan, petitioner, v. Richard M. Nixon
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Four Members of the Court have
disqualified themselves in this case. Because of this absence of a
quorum, 28 U.S.C. § 1, and since a majority of the qualified Justices
are of the opinion that the case cannot be heard and determined at
the next Term of Court, judgment affirmed under 28 U.S.C. § 2109.
No. 74-5060. Thomas LaRuffa, petitioner, v. New York. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals of New York for further consideration in light of
Blacklege v. Perry, 417 U.S. — (1974) and Tollett v. Henderson,
411 U.S. 258 (1973).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. William S. Ellis, Jr., applicant, v. Hawaii; and
-
No. William S. Ellis, Jr., applicant v. George A. Powers et ux.
The motion to consolidate cases to permit filing of a single petition
for writ of certiorari is denied.
No. A-255. Francisco Cepero Alers, applicant, v. Astol Calero
Toledo et al. The application for stay presented to the Chief Justice,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-274. Economic Consultants, Inc., etc., et al., applicants, v.
Mercury Record Productions, Inc., et al. The application for stay of
the mandate of the Supreme Court of Wisconsin, presented to Mr.
Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-334. Lanis Hurst et al., applicants, v. United States. The
application for an order to have court-appointed counsel relieved and

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1974
127
for other relief, presented to Mr. Justice Stewart and by him re-
ferred to the Court, is denied.
No. 50 Original. State of Vermont, plaintiff, v. State of New York
et al. It is ordered by this Court that the Honorable R. Ammi Cutter
be, and he is hereby, awarded the sum of $50,000 as compensation
for his services as Special Master in this case, and that his disburse-
ments totaling $5,150 be allowed. It is further ordered that the fee
and disbursements be paid by the parties in the following amounts:
$20,000 by the State of Vermont and $35,150 by the International
Paper Company.
It is further ordered that the Special Master is hereby discharged.
No. 73-689. Michael Anthony Maness, petitioner, v. James R.
Meyers, Presiding Judge. The motion of Texas Criminal Defense
Lawyers Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is
denied.
No. 73–820. United States, petitioner, v. Pascual Guana-Sanchez.
The motion for the appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered
that Joseph Beeler, Esquire, of Miami, Florida, a member of the Bar
of this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for
the respondent in this case.
No. 73-822. Ernest Fry and Thelma Boehm, petitioners, v. United
States. The motion of the State of California for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied. The motion of California
State Employees' Association for leave to participate in oral argument,
as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73-1012. Gulf Oil Corporation et al., petitioners, v. Copp
Paving Company, Inc., et al. The motion of American Building Main-
tenance Industries for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73–1018. United States, petitioner, v. Martin Dewalt Mazurie
et al. The motion of respondents to dismiss the writ of certiorari is
denied. The motion of the State of Wyoming for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 73–1256. Connell Construction Company, Inc., petitioner, v.
Plumbers and Steamfitters Local No. 100, etc. The motion of Associ-
ated General Contractors of America et al., for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amici curiae, is denied.
No. 73–1279. The Williams and Wilkins Company, petitioner, v.
United States. The motion of The National Education Association
for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 73-1380. Chemehuevi Tribe of Indians et al., petitioners, v.
Federal Power Commission et al.;

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1974
No. 73-1666. Arizona Public Service Company et al., petitioners,

No. 73-1573. Harold Withrow et al., etc., appellants, v. Duane

to oral argument.

the Superior Court of California, County of Sacramento, presented to
Mr. Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court, is denied.

District Court for the Western District of Tennessee, Western Divi-
sion, et al. The application to stay the orders of Judge Robert M. Mc-
Rae entered August 22, 1974, presented to Mr. Justice Stewart and
by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 74-456. John Hill, Attorney General of Texas, et al. appel-
lants, v. Printing Industries of the Gulf Coast et al. The motion of
appellees to vacate the stay entered by this Court on October 11, 1974.
is denied.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit during the week of Janu-
ary 13, 1975, and for such additional time as may be required to
complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is
ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
§ 295.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1974
143
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73-6969. Ross Douglas Ring, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1882. Kevin J. Burns, etc., et al., appellants, v. Karen
Hein, etc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Iowa. Motion of appellee for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Southern District of Iowa for
reconsideration in light of the revision of the regulations of the De-
partment of Agriculture. (See 7 C.F.R. $ 271.3(c) (1) (iii) (f))
No. 73-1890. Ralph B. Thompson et ux., appellants, v. James H.
Clark, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 74-5187. Tyler Henry Smith, II, appellant, v. California. Ap-
peal from the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of Cali-
fornia, County of Alameda. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 73–1929. Ellen P. McDonald et al., appellants, v. John Mc-
Lucas et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73–7089. Charles M. Wright, etc., et al., appellants, v. James
E. Malloy, Commissioner, Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles.
580-278-74--19

144
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1974
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Ver-
mont. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-6884. Samuel Hunter, appellant, v. General Motors Corp.,
Buick Motor Division. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 73–6899. Robert Lee Stokes, appellant, v. Harold J. Buchig-
nani, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Kentucky. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 74-200. Dwight W. Barnett, appellant, v. Irl L. Gordon. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-224. Beacon Enterprises, Inc., appellant, v. City of Colum-
bus, Ohio. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 74-315. Jack Hoogasian et al., appellants, v. Regional Trans-
portation Authority et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-5021. Allen Lovette Grier, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgement of the Court of
Appeals and the sentence imposed by the United States District Court
for the Western District of North Carolina (but not the judgment of
conviction) vacated, and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Western District of North Carolina for reconsideration
in light of Dorszynski v. United States, 418 U.S.— (1974).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. The joint motion for additional time for oral argu-
ment is granted and a total of two hours is allotted for that purpose.
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
No. A-361. Wilbert Baylor, applicant, v. John R. Hess, Judge of
the Superior Court of the District of Columbia. The application for a
writ of mandamus, presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred
to the Court, is denied.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1974
145
No. 73–820. United States, petitioner, v. Pascual Guana-Sanchez.
The motion of the respondent to dismiss the writ on account of moot-
ness is denied.
No. 73-848. Jack A. Fusari, Commissioner of Labor of the State of
Connecticut, Administrator, Unemployment Compensation Act, ap-
pellant, v. Larry Steinberg et al. The motion for the appointment of
counsel is granted, and it is ordered that John M. Creane, Esquire, of
Milford, Connecticut, a member of the Bar of this Court be, and he
is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the appellees in this case.
No. 73-1106. William Cousins et al., petitioners, v. Paul T. Wigoda
et al. The motion of the petitioners for divided argument is denied.
No. 73-1346. John L. McLucas, Secretary of the Air Force, et al.,
appellants, v. Raymond G. DeChamplain. The motion of the appellee
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The motion of the
appellees for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 73-1377. Russell E. Train, Administrator, United States En-
vironmental Protection Agency, petitioner, v. City of New York et al.;
and
No. 73-1378. Russell E. Train, Administrator, United States En-
vironmental Protection Agency, petitioner, v. Campaign Clean Water,
Inc. The motion of the petitioner for additional time for oral argu-
ment is denied.
No. 73–1446. Joan Roe, Peter Poe and Coe Press, Inc., petitioners,
v. Jane Doe. The motion of the Authors League of America for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied. The motion of the American
Psychiatric Association et al., for leave to participate in oral argument,
as amici curiae, is denied.
No. 73-1462. Mark White et al., appellants, v. Diana Regester et
al. The motion of the appellees for additional time for oral argument
is denied.
No. 73–1471. United States et al., petitioners, v. New Jersey State
Lottery Commission. The motion of the petitioners to defer oral argu-
ment is denied.
No. 74–8. J. B. O'Connor, petitioner, v. Kenneth Donaldson. The
motion of Daniel S. Dearing, Esquire, to permit Raymond W. Gearey
to present oral argument pro hac vice on behalf of the petitioner is
granted.
No. 74-70. Lewis H. Goldfarb et al., petitioners, v. Virginia State
Bar et al. The motion of the Virginia State Bar to be dismissed as a
party respondent is denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.

146
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1974
No. 74-170. Robert James Andrino, petitioner, v. United States.
The application for bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 74–518. Howard B. Levy, petitioner, v. Jacob J. Parker,
Warden, et al. The application for a stay of the execution and enforce-
ment of the mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred
to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant the stay
pending the decision of this Court in No. 73-1346, McLucas v. De-
Champlain. The motion to expedite and the motion to consolidate with
No. 73-1346 for oral argument are denied.
No. 74-5492. Leddrew Lee Snider, aka "Buck" Snider, petitioner,
v. United States. The application for stay of execution and enforce-
ment of the judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. 74-5496. Kelsey D. Bartlett, petitioner, v. Toledo Bar Asso-
ciation. The application for stay of execution and enforcement of
judgment of the Supreme Court of Ohio, presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 74-214. Caspar Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education
and Welfare, et al., appellants, v. Concetta Salfi et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Cali-
fornia. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73-1908. Stewart S. Cort et al., petitioners, v. Richard A. Ash,
etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.
No. 74–124. Blue Chip Stamps et al., petitioners, v. Manor Drug
Stores, etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 74–215. United States, petitioner, v. John R. Park. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit granted.
No. 73-1924. James R. Muniz et al., petitioners, v. Roy O. Hoff-
man. Director, Region 20, National Labor Relations Board. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1974
147
Ninth Circuit granted limited to Questions 3 and 4 presented by the
petition which read as follows:
"3. Whether petitioners, charged with criminal contempt for an
alleged violation of an injunction issued under the National Labor
Relations Act, are entitled to a trial by jury under 18 U.S.C. § 3692,
which provides that alleged contemnors are entitled to a jury trial in
all contempt cases ‘arising under the laws of the United States govern-
ing the issuance of injunctions or restraining orders in any case involv-
ing or growing out of a labor dispute.'
"4. Whether Article III, Section 2 and the Sixth Amendment to the
Constitution mandate a jury trial where a penalty of $25,000.00 is
assessed against a labor organization in a criminal contempt
proceeding."
No. 73–2000. United States, petitioner, v. James Robert Peltier.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit granted. Case set for oral argument in tandem with
No. 73-2050, U.S. v. Ortiz; No. 73-6848, Bowen v. U.S; and No. 74-114,
U.S. v. Brignoni-Ponce.
CERTIORARI DENIED

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1974
173
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-155. Randy James Dennis, appellant, v. Oklahoma. Ap-
peal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-341. Lewis B. Wheeler et al., appellants, v. Carl P. Monroe
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Mexico. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-218. Archie H. Divine, Jr., Sheriff of Rock County, Wis-
consin, appellant, v. Myron M. Amato. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of Hamling v. United States, - U.S. - (1974) and the decision of the
Supreme Court of Wisconsin in State ex rel. Chobot v. Circuit Court.
61 Wis. 2d 354, 212 N.W. 2d 690 (1973). Mr. Justice Douglas, being of
the view that any state or federal ban on, or regulation of, obscenity
is prohibited by the Constitution, Roth v. United States, 354 U.S. 476,
508–514; Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15, 42-47; Paris Adult Theatre
I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49, 70–73, and that the Constitution prohibits re-
troactive application of judicially improvised obscenity standards,
Miller v. California, supra, at 37-42. would affirm the judgment below.
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall
would affirm the judgment.
No. 74–5327. Saul Robinowitz, appellant, v. Francis Sargent, Gov-
ernor of Massachusetts et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of ju-
risdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-5372. Ernest Thalasinos, appellant, v. Luigi Dolcino et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Hampshire. The appeal is dis-
580-278-74- -23

174
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1974
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION:
No. 74-108. Paul Regan, Chairman of the New York State Board
of Parole, et al., petitioners, v. Thomas Johnson. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of New York with directions to dismiss the cause as moot.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-340. William L. Calley, Jr., applicant, v. Howard H. Cal-
laway, Secretary of the Army, et al. The application to vacate the
stay entered by United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
on September 26, 1974, presented to Mr. Justice Powell and by him
referred to the Court, is denied as moot.
No. A-386. The Republic of Viet-Nam, applicant, v. Pfizer, Inc., et
al. The application for injunction, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-392. Howard G. Reamer, applicant, v. George Beall, United
States Attorney, et al. The application for stay of the judgment of
the United States District Court for the District of Maryland, pre-
sented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court, is granted
pending further order of the Court.
No. D-24. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael B. Nitsberg. It
is ordered that Michael B. Nitsberg, Esquire, of New York, New
York, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-27. In the Matter of Disbarment of Francis X. McDer-
mott. It is ordered that Francis X. McDermott, Esquire, of New
York, New York, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court
and that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him
to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of
law in this Court.
No. D-28. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert S. Buttles. It is
ordered that Robert S. Buttles, Esquire, of New York, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

Cleary, Esquire, of San Diego, California, a member of the Bar of

respondent in this case.

motion of petitioner for the appointment of counsel is granted, and
it is ordered that Michael D. Nasatir, Esquire, of Beverly Hills,
California, a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby
appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 74-13. Garrell S. Mullaney et al., petitioners, v. Stillman E.
Wilbur, Jr. The motion of the respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The motion for appointment of counsel
is granted, and it is ordered that Peter J. Rubin, Esquire. of Portland,
Maine, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the
respondent in this case.
No. 74-114. United States, petitioner, v. Felix Humberto Brig-
noni-Ponce. The motion of respondent for appointment of counsel is
granted, and it is ordered that John J. Cleary, Esquire, of San Diego,
California, a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby,
appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73-1231. Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Co., petitioner,
v. National Labor Relations Board et al.; and
No. 73–1234. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Truck
Drivers Union Local No. 413, et al. One and one half hours allowed
for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Norton J. Come for the NLRB, by
Mr. Lawrence M. Cohen for Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Co.,
and by Mr. Laurence Gold for respondent Unions.
No. 73-765. International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, Up-
per South Department, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Quality Manufac-
turing Company et al. Argued by Mr. Bernard Dunau for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. John E. Jenkins, Jr., for the respondents.
No. 73-1363. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. J.
Weingarten, Inc. Argued by Mr. Patrick Hardin for the petitioner
and by Mr. Neil Martin for the respondent.
No. 73-1121. North Georgia Finishing, Inc., petitioner, v. Di-
Chem, Inc. Argued by Mr. Warren N. Coppedge, Jr. for the petitioner
and by Mr. L. Hugh Kemp for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 73–375. William Otte, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Freedom-
land, Inc., petitioner, v. United States and the City of New York. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 73-628. Allenberg Cotton Company, Inc., appellant, v. Ben
E. Pittman. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Missis-
sippi for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 73–5768. Frank Xavier Francisco, petitioner, v. J. S. Gath-
right, Superintendent, Bland Correctional Farm. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1974
193
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–1626. Edward T. Weaver et al., appellants, v. Corine Randle
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois, Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-5349. Luella Skufca, appellant, v. Pennsylvania. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Western District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1982. United Theatres of Florida, Inc., etc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. Richard E. Gerstein, etc.:
=
No. 73-2056. United Theatres of Florida, Inc., etc., et al. peti-
tioners, v. Richard E. Gerstein, etc., and
No. 73–2057. United Theatres of Florida, Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. Richard E. Gerstein, etc. On petitions for writs of certiorari to
the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District. Petitions for
writs of certiorari granted, judgments vacated and cases remanded
to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District, for further
consideration in light of Little Beaver Theatre, Inc. v. Tobin, 258 So.
2d 30 (Fla. 3rd Dist. 1972).
No. 74-5189. James E. Yeager, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon the representation
of the Solicitor General set forth in his brief for the United States
filed November 1, 1974, judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma
directing that Court to hold a hearing and make appropriate findings
of fact.
580-278-74-26

194
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1974
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No.
Ferinand Graves et al., applicants, v. James T.
Lynn, Secretary, Department of Housing and Urban Development
et al. The motion to dispense with printing the petition is denied.
No.
David T. Dellinger et al., applicants, v. United
States. The motion to dispense with printing portions of the appendix
to the petition is granted.
No. A-385. Allan G. Kaplan, petitioner, v. United States Postal
Service et al. The application for stay, presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-414. John C. Roemer, III, et al., applicants, v. Board of
Public Works of Maryland et al. The application for an injunction,
presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court, is
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall would grant the injunction. The Chief Justice took no part
in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. 73-1256. Connell Construction Company, Inc., petitioner, v.
Plumbers and Steamfitters Local Union No. 100, etc. The motion of
the Chamber of Commerce of the United States for leave to file a
reply brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73–1543. Willie Johnson, Jr., petitioner, v. Railway Express
Agency, Inc., et al. The motion of the respondents for divided argu-
ment is granted.
No. 73–6642. Terry Lee Crosby et al., petitioners, v. J. William
Middendorf, II, Secretary of the Navy. The motion to consolidate
this case with Nos. 74-175 and 74-5176 is denied.
No. 73–7031. Jesse Thurman Fowler, petitioner, v. North Carolina.
The motion of Richard A. Heim for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, is granted.
No. 74–5567. Francisco Cepero Alers, appellant, v. Municipality
of San Juan. The application for stay, presented to the Chief Justice
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.

OPINION
No. 73-300. William B. Saxbe, Attorney General, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Robert Bustos et al.; and
No. 73-480. Cristobal Cardona et al., petitioners, v. William B.
Saxbe, Attorney General, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed in part and reversed in part and cases remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-360. Will Lewis, applicant, v. United States. The order
entered by Mr. Justice Douglas on November 2, 1974, releasing ap-
plicant from custody upon his own recognizance, is continued pend-
ing final disposition of the petition for a writ of certiorari in case No.
74-439, Will Lewis v. United States.
,
No. A-392. Howard G. Reamer, applicant, v. George Beall, United
States Attorney, et al. The order entered by the Court on November 18,
1974, staying the judgment of the United States District Court for
the District of Maryland is continued conditioned upon the filing of
a petition for writ of certiorari on or before December 24, 1974.
Should such a petition be so filed on or before December 24, 1974, this
order is to continued pending this Court's action on the petition. If

218
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1974
the petition for writ of certiorari is denied, this order is to terminate
automatically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is grant-
ed, this order is to remain in effect pending the sending down of the
judgment of this Court.
Adjourned until Monday, December 9, 1974, at 10 o'clock.
✓

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1974
219
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice.
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-256. American Institute for Shippers' Associations, Inc.
and C-Line, Inc., appellants, v. United States et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Stewart would
note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 74-285. George Transfer and Rigging Company, Incorporated,
appellant, v. United States and Interstate Commerce Commission.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Maryland. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-360. The Long Island Rail Road Company, appellant, v.
United States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of New York. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-471. Lee M. Cassidy et al., appellants, v. Burton D. Willis,
State Election Commissioner, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Delaware. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74–307. B & L Motor Freight, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Ronald
M. Heymann, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New
Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Powell
would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 74–326. David T. Mason, etc., et al., appellants, v. Robert
Francis, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Maryland. Motion of appellee Francis for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari before judgment, certiorari denied.
No. 74–336. Gary P. Smith, dba Holiday Health Club, et al.,
appellants, v. Hervey Keator, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of North Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
580-278-74-28

220
MONDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1974
No. 74-344. Horace H. McCollough, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-426. Fred Joiner et al., appellants, v. City of Dallas, Texas,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Texas. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice White and Mr.
Justice Powell would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 74-5029. Eddie Samuel Ivory, appellant, v. Florida. Appeal
from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Mark Trail Camp Grounds, Inc., petitioner, v. Field
Enterprises, Inc., dba Publishers-Hall Syndicate. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 71-6356. John Doe et al., petitioners, v. John L. McMillan et al.
The motion of petitioners for clarification of the opinion of this Court
is denied.
No. 73-662. James R. Schlesinger et al., petitioners, v. Bruce R.
Councilman. The motion of respondent for divided argument is
granted.
No. 73–717. Alexander J. Antoine et ux., appellants, v. Washing-
ton. The motion of appellee to strike the brief of the United States, as
amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73-1016. John Lascaris, etc., appellant, v. Sylvia Shirley, etc.,
et al.; and
No. 73-1095. Abe Lavine, etc., appellant, v. Sylvia Shirley, etc.,
et al. The motion of Isadore Greenberg, Esquire, to permit Douglas A.
Eldredge, Esquire, to present oral argument, pro hac vice, on behalf
of appellee Stuck is granted. The motion of the State of Iowa for
leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73–1462. Mark White et al., appellants, v. Diana Regester et al.
The motion of appellees for divided argument is granted.
No. 73-1500. Don R. Erickson, Warden, petitioner, v. John Lee
Feather et al. The motion of respondents for divided argument is
granted.
No. 73–1631. Louis Ostrer, petitioner, v. United States. The
motion to modify the denial of certiorari is denied.
No. 73–2000. United States, petitioner, v. James Robert Peltier.
-The motion for appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered
that Sandor W. Shapery, Esquire, of LaJolla, California, be, and he
is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.

221
No. 73-6923. Milton James Rice et al., petitioners, v. United
States. The motion of Gloria Mae Gilmore et al. to join in the petition
is granted.
No. 74-520. Ernest L. Montanye, Former Superintendent, Attica
Correctional Facility, et al., petitioners, v. Rodney R. Haymes. The
motion to expedite is denied.
No. 74-5140. Michael J. Cassius, petitioner, v. Arizona. The motion
of petitioner to permit Frederick S. Klein, Esquire, to present oral
argument, pro hac vice, is granted.

No. 74-453. Barry Van Lare, etc., et al., appellants, v. Rose Hurley,
etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the South-
ern and Eastern Districts of New York. The application for stay
presented to Mr. Justice Marshall, and by him referred to the Court,
is denied. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted. Case set for oral argu-
ment in tandem with No. 74–5054.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit granted.

of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit granted.

Second Circuit granted. Case set for oral argument in tandem with No.
74-453.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired), to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit during the week of March 10, 1975.
and for such additional time as may be required to complete unfinished
business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on the
minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1974
247
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74–225. John Marshall and Queen City News, Inc., appellants,
v. Ohio; and
No. 74-226. Michael Kensinger, appellant, v. Ohio. Appeals from
the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Hamilton County. The stays hereto
granted on July 9, 1974, by Mr. Justice Stewart are vacated. The ap-
peals are dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart
and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Separate dissenting statement by Mr.
Justice Douglas.
No. 74-284. District of Columbia, appellant, v. Hubert Walters
et al. Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a properly presented federal question.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. The Chief Justice and Mr. Jus-
tice White would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 74-478. Dimitrios Garis, appellant, v. Compania Maritima San
Basilio, S. A., et al. Appeal from the Appellate Division of the
Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial Department. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-5376. Miguel A. Gargallo, appellant. v. Tecla Gargallo.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin County. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 74-5403. Robert Martinolich, appellant, r. Pennsylvania.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
580-278-71- -32

248
MONDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1974
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 74–474. James E. Conklin, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74–499. Edward Fitzgerald et al., appellants, v. Robert J.
diGrazia, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Missouri. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Missouri for entry of a fresh judgment or decree from which a
timely appeal may be taken to the United States Court of Appeals.
Gonzalez v. Automatic Employees Credit Union, — U.S.
-
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
(1974).
No. 73–1739. Gloria Sandquist, petitioner. v. California. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Department of the Su-
perior Court of California, County of Los Angeles; and
No. 74-158. Earl Kuhns and Richard Castner, petitioners, v. Cali-
fornia; and
No. 74-159. Earl Kulins and Richard Castner, petitioners, v. Cali-
fornia. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the Appellate Depart-
ment of the Superior Court of California. County of Santa Cruz. The
petitioners did not seek to have the Appellate Department certify
their cases to the Court of Appeal pursuant to California Penal Code
§ 1471, California Rules of Court, Rules 62, 63. Accordingly, the de-
cisions of the Appellate Department are not a "(f)inal judgment . . .
rendered by the highest court of a State in which a decision could be
had.... 28 U.S.C. § 1257, and the petitions for writs of certiorari to
their respective courts are dismissed for want of jurisdiction. See
Banks v. California, 395 U.S. 708 (1969).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-430. Noble C. Beasley, applicant, v. United States. The
application for reduction of bail pending appeal, presented to Mr.
Justice White and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 73-1256. Connell Construction Company, Inc., petitioner. ".
Plumbers and Steamfitters Local Union No. 100, etc. The motion of
the petitioner for leave to file a brief, after argument, is granted.
No. 73–6739. Steven Costarelli, appellant, v. Massachusetts. The
motion of the appellant for appointment of counsel is granted, and it
is ordered that Robert W. Hagopian. Esquire, of Wrentham, Massa-
chusetts, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the
appellant in this case.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1974
249
No. 74–157. United Housing Foundation, Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. Milton Forman et al. The motion to defer consideration of the
petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 74-201. City of Richmond, Virginia, appellant, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Columbia. Motion of appellee Holt for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
matter.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 74-415. Francis A. Rondeau, petitioner, v. Mosinee Paper
Corporation. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted.
No. 74-450. Alexander P. Butterfield, Administrator, Federal
Aviation Administration, et al., petitioners, v. Reuben B. Robertson,
III, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit granted.
No. 74-452. Twentieth Century Music Corporation et al., petition-
ers, v. George Aiken. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.
No. 74-466. Peter J. Brennan, Secretary of Labor, petitioner, v.
Walter Bachowski. Petition for writ to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.
No. 74–121. Craig Phelps, Receiver in Bankruptcy, petitioner, v.
United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted limited to Ques-
tions 1, 2 and 3 presented by the petition which read as follows:
"First: Whether the Court of Appeals incorrectly granted to the
United States a priority based up the Internal Revenue Code of 1954
for taxes in violation of and contrary to the priorities for payment
of claims established by the Bankruptcy Act?
"Second: Whether the Court of Appeals incorrectly held that service
of a Notice of Levy upon an assignee for the benefit of creditors sub-
sequent to the assignment reduced the bankrupt's property then held.
by the assignee to the constructive possession of the United States?

250
MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1974
"Third: Whether the Court of Appeals incorrectly determined that
the Bankruptcy Court lacked summary jurisdiction to adjudicate the
controversy before it without the consent of the United States?"
No. 74-389. Albemarle Paper Company et al., petitioners, v. Joseph
P. Moody et al.; and
No. 74-428. Halifax Local No. 425, United Papermakers and Pa-
perworkers, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Joseph P. Moody et al. Petitions
for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit granted, Cases consolidated and a total of one hour
allotted for oral argument. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of these petitions.

ASSIGNMENT ORDERS
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit on December 13, 1974, and for such
additional time as may be required to complete unfinished business,
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on the minutes of
this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit during the week of May 26, 1975, and
for such additional time as may be required to complete unfinished
business pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on the
minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

eral Insurance Corporation et al. Appeals from the United States

reversed and case remanded to the United States District Court for the

nan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting statement

MONDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1974

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice

The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
j
No. 73-711. John Cryan et al., appellants, v. Hamar Theaters, Inc.,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of New Jersey. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of New Jersey to determine
whether the cause is moot in light of State v. DeSantis, 65 N. J. 462
(1974).
No. 73-7014. George H. Jones, appellant, v. Florida. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
properly presented federal question. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall join.
No. 74-67. Fagan Dickson, appellant, v. Gerald R. Ford and Elmer
Staats. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western
District of Texas. This is an appeal, assertedly brought under 28
U.S.C. § 1253, from a three-judge court order dismissing a complaint
which sought to enjoin a federal statute upon the ground of its uncon-
stitutionality, 28 U.S.C. § 2282. The court found the case "non-justici-
able" because the appellant lacked standing to sue and because the
case involved a "political question." Where a three-judge court dis-
misses a complaint as being non-justiciable, appeal does not lay to this
Court under 28 U.S.C. § 1253. Gonzalez v. Automatic Employees Cred-
it Union, U.S. (1974). Accordingly, the order is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States District Court for the
Western District of Texas so that a fresh order may be entered from
which a timely appeal may be taken to the United States Court of
Appeals. 28 U.S.C. § 1291.
-
-
No. 74–69. Rosa Padilla, appellant, v. Abe Lavine, etc., et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
580-278-74-35

268
MONDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1974
No. 74-434. Colorado Civil Rights Commission, etc., appellant,
v. Colorado, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Colorado.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-5486. Claude E. Brimm, appellant, v. Workmen's Com-
pensation Appeals Board et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, Second Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for
sant of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-235. Harold Seidernfaden and Louisville Professional
Firefighters' Association, Local Union No. 345, I.A.F.F., AFL-CIO,
appellants, v. City of Louisville, Division of Fire, Safety Director,
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jursidiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas would postpone further consideration of the
question of jurisdiction to a hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 74-437. Lonnie North, appellant, v. C. B. Russell et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. Upon the representa-
tion of the Attorney General of Kentucky set forth in his motion to
dismiss or affirm filed in this Court on November 29, 1974, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky for
further consideration in light of the position presently asserted by the
Commonwealth.
No. 74-517. Alexander R. Mercer et al., appellants, v. Michigan
State Board of Education et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Eastern District of Michigan. Judgment af-
firmed. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
White would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES

certiorari in No. 74-759, presented to the Chief Justice and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.

him referred to the Court, is denied.

et al. The application for stay of execution of judgment upon remit-
titur, presented to Mr. Justice Rehnquist and by him referred to the
Court, is denied.

tion for bail pending appeal, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and
by him referred to the Court, is denied.

269

sas. Amended decree entered.
