argument.
No. 73–1808. James Burnett McKay Laing, petitioner, v. United
States et al.; and
No. 74-75. United States et al., petitioners, v. Elizabeth Jane Hall.
The motion to consolidate for oral argument is granted.
No. 73–1933. United States, appellant, v. Citizens and Southern
National Bank et al. The motion of Independent Bankers Association
of Georgia, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 73–6650. Richard Brown, petitioner, v. Illinois. The motion
of John Thomas Moran, Jr., Esquire, to permit Robert P. Isaacson,
Esquire, to present oral argument, pro hav vice, on behalf of petitioner,
is granted.
No. 74-668. Sheldon Selikoff, petitioner, v. New York. The applica-
tion for stay of incarceration, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by
him referred to the Court, is denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No: 74–456. John Hill, Attorney General of Texas, et al., appel-
lants, v. Printing Industries of the Gulf Coast et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas. In
this case probable jurisdiction noted.

OPINIONS
No. 73-5845. Catherine Jackson, etc., petitioner, v. Metropolitan
Edison Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall.
No. 73–1270. Eugene C. Kelley, petitioner, v. Southern Pacific
Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan concurs. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1974
279
No. 73-1055. Bowman Transportation, Inc., appellant, v. Arkan-
sas-Best Freight System, Inc., et al.;
No. 73–1069. Johnson Motor Lines, Inc., appellant, v. Arkansas-
Best Freight System, Inc., et al.;
No. 73-1070. Red Ball Motor Freight, Inc., appellant, v. Arkansas-
Best Freight System, Inc., et al.;
No. 73–1071. Lorch-Westway Corporation et al., appellants, v.
Arkansas-Best Freight System, Inc., et al.; and
No. 73–1072. United States and Interstate Commerce Commission,
appellants, v. Arkansas-Best Freight System, Inc., et al. Appeals
from the United States District Court for the Western District of
Arkansas. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the United
States District Court for the Western District of Arkansas for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 73–1231. Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Co., petitioner,
v. National Labor Relations Board et al.; and
No. 73–1234. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Truck
Drivers Union Local No. 413 et al. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart
with whom Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Powell join.
No. 73–5677. Maurice Schick, petitioner, v. George J. Reed, Chair-
man of the United States Board of Parole, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan join.
Adjourned until Monday, January 13, 1975, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1975
281
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-2045. American Plant Food Corporation, appellant, v.
Texas. Appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74–253. Stanley Earl Sobottka, appellant, v. Rachel Brown,
Registrar of Voters of Albemarle County. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 74-413. Benny Frankie Cerezo, appellant, v. Walter Buso et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-380. Louisiana State Board of Medical Examiners et al.,
appellants, v. I. I. Rosen, M.D. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice White, with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins, concurring:
Under the compulsion of Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113 (1973), and Doe
v. Bolton, 410 U.S. 179 (1973), which in my view were erroneously
decided, I join the affirmance.
No. 74-402. Erwin W. Rastetter et al., appellants, v. Caspar W.
Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the District of Arizona.
Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-5136. Hercules Alexander Young et al., appellants, v.
Ralph L. Cobb, Sr., etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Florida. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-5425. L. G. Ruderer, appellant, v. Harlington Wood, Jr.
and James L. Foreman. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Southern District of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction.
580-278-75-36
1-

282
MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1975
No. 74-5571. Curtis Lee Ray, Pamela Ray and Donna Ray,
appellants, v. Arthur Hedgewald, John Doe and Lucille Roebuck.
Chairman, Kentucky State Parole Board. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Western District of Kentucky. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 74-5567. Francisco Cepero Alers, appellant, v. Municipality
of San Juan. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-5577. Charlotte R. Hurd, appellant. v. Robert S. Hurd.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-5583. Theophalus Turner, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-83. Armando Pelliccioni, petitioner, v. Schuyler Packing
Company et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Superior
Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to Superior
Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division, for further consideration
in light of Kelley v. Southern Pacific Co., U.S. (1974).
-
No. 74-5352. John Ackerson, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon the representation
of the Solicitor General set forth in his brief for the United States
filed December 19, 1974. judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri
to permit the government to dismiss the charges against the petitioner.
The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-285. Helene Wohlgemuth, applicant. v. Planned Parent-
hood Association of Southeastern Pennsylvania, Inc., et al. The appli-
cation to vacate the preliminary injunction, presented to Mr. Justice
Rehnquist and by him referred to the Court, is denied.

MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1975

No. A-566. California, et al. applicants, v. Peter J. Brennan. The
stay order heretofore granted by the Chief Justice on December 31,
1974, is hereby continued on condition that the appellants file their
jurisdictional statement on or before January 17, 1975. The appellee
may file a reply to the jurisdictional statement on or before 12 ■.m.,
January 23, 1975. Neither the jurisdictional statement nor the reply
need be initially printed.

Fifth Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Powell and by him referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. D-25. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Arthur Dale Leach.
It is ordered that Arthur Dale Leach. Esquire, of Silver Spring,
Maryland, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. D-26. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank S. Ketcham.
It is ordered that Frank S. Ketcham. Esquire, of Potomac, Maryland,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be barred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-28. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert S. Buttles-
Disbarment entered.

ordered that John A. Ross, Jr., Esquire. of New York, New York,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule.
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied.

writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth
Appellate District, denied.

of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied.

for leave to file petition for writ of certiorari denied.

et al.;

trict Court; and

for writ of mandamus and/or prohibition and/or certiorari denied.

of the cases in which orders or judgments are this day announced.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit during the month of January 1975,
and for such additional time as may be required to complete unfin-
ished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on
the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

OPINIONS
No. 73-762. Carol Maureen Sosna, etc., appellant, v. Iowa et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Iowa. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 73–1313. International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation,
Communications Equipment and Systems Division, petitioner, v. Local
134, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL-CIO.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 73-848. Jack A. Fusari, Commissioner of Labor of the State
of Connecticut, Administrator, Unemployment Compensation Act,
appellant, v. Larry Steinberg et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the District of Connecticut. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the District
of Connecticut for further proceedings in light of the intervening
changes in Connecticut law. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.

v. Sears, Roebuck and Co. Argued by Mr. Daniel M. Friedman for
the petitioners and by Mr. Gerard C. Smetana for the respondent.

Court of Illinois, First District, for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring in the result, with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Stewart join. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part and dissenting in part.

Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart concurring in the result, with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun
joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in the result.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 20, 1975
307
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-5433. Michael John Kovach, Jr., appellant, v. Edward F.
Schubert, Superintendent, Central State Hospital. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 74-5710. Tyler Henry Smith, II, appellant, v. California.
Appeal from the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of
California, County of Kern. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 74-5617. Robert Randolph Nickens, appellant, v. Virginia.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-33. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald F. McDonald,
Jr. It is ordered that Ronald F. McDonald, Jr., Esquire, of Rockville,
Maryland, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that
a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. D-34. In the matter of Disbarment of Elaine Worley Kerr.
It is ordered that Elaine Worley Kerr of Bailey's Crossroads, Virginia,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring her to show cause why
she should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-35. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas Paul Raimondi.
It is ordered that Thomas Paul Raimondi, Esquire, of Baltimore,
Maryland, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
580-278-75- 40

308
MONDAY, JANUARY 20, 1975
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. D-36. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stanley J. Bomstein. It
is ordered that Stanley J. Bomstein, Esquire, of Baltimore, Maryland,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-37. In the Matter of Disbarment of Christopher Ker
Hankinson. It is ordered that Christopher Ķer Hankinson, Esquire,
of Vienna, Virginia, be suspended from the practice of law in this
Court and that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.
No. 73–1933. United States, appellant, v. Citizens and Southern
National Bank et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for addi-
tional time for oral argument is granted and fifteen additional minutes
are allotted for that purpose. The appellees are allotted fifteen addi-
tional minutes for oral argument.
No. 74-8. J. B. O'Connor, petitioner, v. Kenneth Donaldson. The
motion of Texas et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 74–337. Frank Dóran, etc., appellant, v. Salem Inn, Inc., et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JANUARY 21, 1975
321
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell,
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
OPINIONS
No. 73–1018. United States, petitioner, v. Martin Dewalt Mazurie
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 73–5744. Billy J. Taylor, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White. Statement by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the
result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73–1808. James Burnett McKay Laing, petitioner, v. United
States et al.; and
No. 74-75. United States et al., petitioners, v. Elizabeth Jane Hall.
Two hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Stuart A. Smith
for the United States et al., by Mr. Donald M. Heavrin for Elizabeth
Jane Hall, and by Mr. Joseph S. Oteri for James Burnett McKay
Laing.
No. 73-1452. Oregon, petitioner, v. William Robert Hass. Argued
by Mr. Thomas H. Denney for the petitioner and by Mr. Sam A. Mc-
Keen for the respondent.
No. 74-5140. Michael J. Cassius, petitioner, v. Arizona. Argued
by Mr. Frederick S. Klein for the petitioner, pro hac vice, by special
leave of Court and by Mr. William J. Schafer, III, for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 22, 1975
323
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ADMISSION TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTION
Applicant
Michael P. McCabe
City and State
Movant
Concord, Calif.
OPINIONS
Thomas J. Dillon.
No. 73-898. Norval Goss et al., appellants, v. Eileen Lopez et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Ohio. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 73-1121. North Georgia Finishing, Inc., petitioner, v. Di-
Chem, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Georgia for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Statement by Mr. Justice
Stewart concurring in the judgment and opinion. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins and
Mr. Chief Justice Burger dissents for the reasons stated in paragraph 5.
No. 73–1697. Standard Pressed Steel Co., appellant, v. Depart-
ment of Revenue, State of Washington. Appeal from the Court of
Appeals of Washington, Division II. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice.
Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 74-5369. Willie J. Daniel, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-678. Edward P. Gallogly et al., appellants, v. Raymond J.
Larsen. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Rhode Island. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Rhode Island with directions
to dismiss the case as moot. See Sosna v. Iowa, 419 U.S.
and United States v. Munsingwear, 340 U.S. 36 (1950).
(1975)
No. 73-1248. South Dakota et al., appellants, v. Elta M. McCay
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District.
of South Dakota. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United.
States District Court for the District of South Dakota with directions
to dismiss the case as moot. See Sosna v. Iowa, 419 U.S.
and United States v. Munsingwear, 340 U.S. 36 (1950).
_
(1975)
No. 73-5804. Dan Gilbert, Jr., appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. See Daniel v. Louisiana,
U.S.
-
(1975).
No. 73–6598. Edna Stubblefield, appellant, v. Tennessee. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Tennessee. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. See Daniel v.
Louisiana, · U.S. (1975).
No. 74-5280. Jimmy Wayne Devall and Charlotte Devall, appel-
lants, v. Louisiana. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
See Daniel v. Louisiana,

U.S.
(1975).
580-278-75--43

326
MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1975.
No. 74-254. Warren Spannaus, Attorney General of Minnesota,
et al., appellants, v. Jane E. Hodgson et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Minnesota. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. An order granting only a declara-
tory judgment may not be appealed to this Court under 28 U.S.C.
§ 1253. Mitchell v. Donovan, 398 U.S. 427 (1970). It is of no con-
sequence that a preliminary injunction was continued in effect until
determination of this appeal, since no appeal was taken from the
preliminary injunction. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-472. North Central Truck Lines, Inc., appellant, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western District of Missouri. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-602. Port Royal Marine Corporation et al., appellants, v.
United States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Southern District of Georgia. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-481. Virginia, appellant, v. United States et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.
Judgment affirmed. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist
with whom the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Powell join.
No. 74-613. Chamber of Commerce of the United States, appellant,
v. Robert Francis, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Maryland. Motion of appellee Francis for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction.
No. 74-681. Vincent Alexander and Marion Lenzi, appellants, v.
Marguerite D'Allesandro. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 74-693. Margaret C. Mahoney et al., appellants, v. Board of
Appeals of Winchester et al. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court
of Massachusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. The exceptions to the Report of the Special Master
are set for oral argument, Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this order.
No. 35, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Maine et al.
The exceptions to the Report of the Special Master are set for oral
argument and a total of four hours is allotted for that purpose.
No. 73–1701. United States, appellant, v. National Association of
Securities Dealers, Inc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for

MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1975
327
additional time to permit the Securities and Exchange Commission to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, in support of the
appellees, is granted and fifteen minutes are allotted for that purpose.
The appellant is allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 73–1869. Peter H. Beer et al., appellants, v. United States et al.
The motion of appellees Jackson et al. to dismiss the appeal for lack
of prosecution is denied.
No. 73–2050. United States, petitioner, v. Luis Antonio Ortiz; and
No. 73-6848. John Lee Bowen, petitioner v. United States. The
motion of the Solicitor General to consolidate for oral argument is
granted and a total of one and one-half hours allotted for oral argu-
ment. The motion for the appointment of new counsel in No. 73–2050
is granted, and it is ordered that Charles M. Sevilla, Esquire, of San
Diego, California, a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is
hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case,
and John J. Cleary, Esquire, is hereby relieved from his prior
appointment.
No. 74-70. Lewis H. Goldfarb et al., petitioners, v. Virginia State
Bar et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for additional time to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is granted and fifteen
minutes are allotted for that purpose. The respondents are allotted
fifteen additional minutes for oral argument. Mr. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-872. National Society of Professional Engineers. appellant,
v. United States. The motion of the appellant for expedited consider-
ation is denied.

No. 74-879. California, appellant, v. Peter J. Brennan, Secretary

consolidated, and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument.

OPINIONS
No. 73-1406. Daniel Chapman and Jacque Stockman, appellants,
v. Ben Meier, etc. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of North Dakota. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the United States District Court for the District of North Dakota
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 73–5993. John E. Test, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
with instructions to remand to the District Court so that petitioner
may attempt to support his challenge to the jury selection procedures.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Tuesday, February 18, 1975, at 10 o'clock.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1975
339
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 74–439. Will Lewis, petitioner, v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this petition.

580-278-75— -44

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1975
341
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Mr. Solicitor General Bork presented the Honorable Edward H.
Levi, Attorney General of the United States.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Attorney General, the Court welcomes you to the performance
of the important duties which devolve upon you as the chief law officer
of the Government, and as an officer of this Court. Your commission
will be recorded by the Clerk."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73-7006. James P. Lee, Jr. and Ronald Rich, appellants, v.
William Thornton, District Director, United States Customs for
Vermont, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Vermont. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the District of Vermont for consideration of ap-
pellants' other asserted bases of jurisdiction. Opinion per curiam. Mr.
Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-787. Fannie Jefferies, etc., appellant, v. Jule Sugarman, as
Commissioner of the Department of Social Services of the City of
New York, et al.; and
No. 72-5758. Maxine Handel et al., appellants, v. Jule Sugarman,
etc., et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis in No. 72-5758 granted. Judgment vacated and cases re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Southern District
of New York for further consideration in light of Hagans v. Lavine,

415 U.S. 528 (1974). Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-

No. 74-58. Joseph Thompson, appellant, v. Joan Thompson. Ap-
peal from the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. Mo-
tion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion and appeal.
No. 74–606. Maria Rivera Mendez, appellant, v. Louis B. Heller,
etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the East-
ern District of New York. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New
York so that a fresh decree or order may be entered from which a
timely appeal may be taken to the United States Court of Appeals
(28 U.S.C. § 1291). Gonzalez v. Automatic Employees Credit Union
(1974). Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this appeal.

No. 74-674. Economic Consultants, Inc., etc., et al., appellants, v.
Mercury Record Productions, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 74-777. Charles L. Kellar and Cornelia Kellar, appellants, v.
Western Cab Company et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Nevada. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for certiorari.
certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this appeal.
No. 74-808. George Hall, appellant, v. Wisconsin. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 74-707. Dollietta and Kenneth Comenout, appellants, v. Mil-
ton Burdman, etc., et al.; and
No. 74-807. Leonard Tonasket, appellant, v. Washington et al.
Appeals from the Supreme Court of Washington. The motion of the
Quinault Tribe of Indians et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici
curiae, granted. The appeals are dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion and these appeals.

Steed, a minor, appellant, v. Imperial Airlines et al. Appeal from the

v. Carl Onischuk, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Min-
nesota. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-

decision of this appeal.
No. 74-719. Carol Sue Neale et vir, appellants, v. Albert T. Hay-
duk, etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for failure to file the notice of appeal within the
time provided by Rule 11 and 28 U.S.C. § 2101 (c).
No. 74-5497. Robert Duggan, appellant, v. Ted W. Brown, Secre-
tary of State of Ohio. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1015. Ellenmae Crow et al., petitioners, v. California De-
partment of Human Resources Development et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals with directions to consider the question of mootness in
light of Sosna v. Iowa, U.S. (1975) and Indiana Employ-
ment Security Division v. Burney, 409 U.S. 540 (1973). See United
States v. Munsingwear, 340 U.S. 36 (1950). If the court determines
that the case is not moot, it should consider whether a three-judge
court is required. See Hagans v. Lavine, 415 U.S. 528, 543–545 (1974);
-

344
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1975
-
Fusari v. Steinberg, - U.S. — (1975); cf. Idlewild Bon Voyage
Liquor Corp. v. Epstein, 370 U.S. 713, 716 (1962). Mr. Justice Douglas
and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision
of this petition.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 35, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Maine et al.;
and
No. 52, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Florida. The
motion of the Solicitor General for reallocation and reduction of time
for oral argument is granted. It is ordered that a total of three hours
be allotted for oral argument in No. 35 Original and that a total of
one and one half hours be allotted for oral argument in No. 52 Original.
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. A-463. Louis Hajal et al., applicants, v. United States. The
application for bail, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him re-
ferred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this ap-
plication.
No. A-656. Planned Parenthood of Central Missouri et al., ap-
plicants, v. John C. Danforth, Attorney General of Missouri, et al.
The application for stay of the enforcement of "Missouri House Bill
No. 1211" pending appeal, presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun and
by him referred to the Court, is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.
No. D-26. In the matter of Disbarment of Frank S. Ketcham.
Frank S. Ketcham, of Potomac, Maryland, having requested to resign
as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court. The rule to show cause heretofore issued on Janu-
ary 13, 1975, is hereby discharged. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this matter.
No. D-29. In the Matter of Disbarment of George R. Osborne. Dis-
barment entered. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this matter.
No. D-30. In the Matter of Disbarment of Leonard N. Tarr. Dis-
barment entered. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall took
no part in the consideration or decision of this matter.
No. 73-1233. National Labor Relations Board et al., petitioners,
v. Sears, Roebuck and Co. The motion of the respondent for leave
to file a supplemental brief, after argument, is granted. Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Powell took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.

No. 73-1908. Stewart S. Cort et al., petitioners, v. Richard A. Ash,

file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.

motions.
No. 74-70. Lewis H. Goldfarb et al., petitioners, v. Virginia State
Bar et al. The motion of The American Dental Association for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of The Na-
tional Organization of Bar Counsel for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
motions.
No. 74-156. Cecil Hicks, District Attorney of the County of
Orange, State of California, et al., appellants, v. Vincent Miranda dba
Walnut Properties et al. The motions for additional time for oral argu-
ment are granted and the appellants are allotted fifteen additional
minutes for that purpose. The appellees are allotted fifteen additional
minutes for oral argument. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-201. City of Richmond, Virginia, appellant, v. United
States et al. The joint motion for additional time for oral argument
is granted, and a total of one hour and twenty minutes is allotted for
that purpose. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 74-304. Richard A. Gordon et al., petitioners, v. New York
Stock Exchange, Inc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General to
permit the United States and the Securities and Exchange Commis-
sion to participate in oral argument, as amici curiae, is granted and
a total of forty additional minutes is allotted for that purpose. Mr.
Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-452. Twentieth Century Music Corporation et al., peti-
tioners, v. George Aiken. The motion of The Authors League of
America, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. Mr.
Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.

lants, v. Printing Industries of the Gulf Coast et al. The motion of
Common Cause for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.

as follows: "1. Whether Title 18 U.S.C. Section 922 (h) applies to
petitioner who purchased a firearm in an intrastate transaction, and
was not involved in any manner with the interstate transportation of
said firearm." Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion and petition.

cuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition."

denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this petition.
No. 74-5779. Robert V. Pace, petitioner, v. Massachusetts. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.
No. 74-5780. Leroy Davenport, petitioner, v. Illinois. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First Judicial
District, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this petition.
No. 74-5783. Ernest L. Coleman, petitioner, v. Michigan. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Michigan denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.
No. 74-5785. Leo Ernest Aleck, petitioner, v. Washington. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Washington,
Division III, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.
No. 74-5792. James H. Vaughan et ux, petitioners, v. Spencer G.
Gill, Judge of the Circuit Court of the City of Norfolk et al. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 74-5793. Jose Franco Padilla, petitioner, v. New Mexico. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.
No. 74–5795. James Doyle Newton, petitioner, v. California. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Fifth
Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.

fornia, First Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no

sion of this petition.
No. 74-293. Pennsylvania, petitioner, v. Angelo Weeden and
Major Reed. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of Pennsylvania, Western District, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and petition.
No. 74-454. Raymond K. Procunier, Director, California Depart-
ment of Corrections, petitioner, v. Calvin Vase Valrie. Motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California denied.
No. 74-496. Roddie Crooks, Jr., petitioner, v. Washington. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Washington,
Division I, denied. See Molinaro v. New Jersey, 396 U.S. 365 (1970).
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.
No. 74-623. Kentucky Carbon Corporation et al., petitioners, v.
Interior Board of Mine Operations Appeals et al. Motion of American
Mining Congress for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr. Justice White would
grant certiorari. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion and petition.
No. 74-772. California et al., petitioners, v. Lewis Gordon et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California

364
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1975
denied, there being no present case or controversy such as to confer
jurisdiction on this Court. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 74–5552. James Pilcher, petitioner, v. Mississippi. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi denied with-
out prejudice to an application for writ of habeas corpus in the appro-
priate United States District Court for consideration of questions
not adequately presented by the record before us. These include the
question whether, in view of all of the circumstances attendant upon
the trial, petitioner received a fair trial before an impartial judge
and by an impartial jury as required by the Fourteenth Amendment.
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 74-5644. Cornelius Lucas, petitioner, v. Paul J. Regan, etc.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall dissents from the
denial of certiorari for the reasons stated by Judge Oakes in the court
below. 503 F.2d 1, 5–8 (CA2, 1974). Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this petition.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 74-657. In the Matter of the Petition of Richard Joyce Smith,
Trustee of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Com-
pany, petitioner. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of cer-
tiorari and/or mandamus and/or prohibition denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

den. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas corpus denied.

this motion.

The Chief Justice said:
"The Court is in special session this afternoon, to receive the
Resolutions of the Bar of the Supreme Court in tribute to Mr. Justice
Whittaker."
Mr. Solicitor General Bork addressed the Court as follows:
"Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:
"At a meeting of the members of the Bar of the Supreme Court just
concluded, resolutions expressing profound sorrow at the death of
Mr. Justice Charles Evans Whittaker were offered by a committee,
of which Mr. Samuel Molby was Chairman. Addresses were offered
by Mr. Carl Enggas of the Missouri Bar, Judge Bruce Forrester
of the United States Tax Court, and by Mr. Senator Roman Hruska
of Nebraska.
"The resolutions unanimously adopted are as follows:
We meet to record our respect and regard for Charles Evans
Whittaker, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United
States from 1957 to 1962. His death on November 26, 1973, has saddened
the members of the legal profession, his family, his friends, and those
everywhere who admired and respected him.
Charles Evans Whittaker was born February 22, 1901, near Troy,
Kansas. He spent his early years on his father's farm. In later life,
in addition to recalling the hard work of farming, he also recounted
that he ran a trapline on his way to school. He recalled that his most
frequent quarry was skunks and that while their pelts brought three
dollars each, he also recalled that his popularity at school was not

380
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1975
enhanced, particularly in the winter when cold weather required the
windows to be kept closed.
His formal education was interrupted after completion of the ninth
grade, and he returned to farming and trapping. The interruption
was only temporary, however, because as soon as he had accumulated
$750, he set out for Kansas City to enroll in the University of Kansas
City Law School.
A high school diploma was a requirement of admission, but Justice
Whittaker convinced the Admissions Committee to accept him on
condition that he complete his high school course simultaneously
with his law studies, which he did.
Justice Whittaker once told an interviewer that he had loved the
law since his earliest recollection and he approached his law school
studies in that spirit.
He was graduated from the University of Kansas City Law
School in 1923 and was admitted to practice before the courts of
Missouri in that year. He immediately joined the Kansas City firm
of Watson, Ess & Gage, for whom he had worked as a messenger
while in law school.
In 1928, he married Winifred Pugh. It was a long and happy mar-
riage, and they were to have three sons, Keith, Kent, and Gary, each of
whom now resides in Kansas City.
He fashioned a successful career at the bar, becoming a partner of
his firm in 1930, and he rose to become a leading trial lawyer in Kansas
City, involved primarily in litigation on behalf of corporate clients.
But he believed, with Mr. Justice Brandeis, that every man owes some-
thing to his profession and he was therefore active in the organized
bar, serving as president of the Missouri Bar Association in 1953 to
1954.
In that year, 1954, he was appointed to the United States District
Court for the Western District of Missouri, and served in that capacity
until June 22, 1956, when he was appointed a judge of the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
As a district judge, he continued the hard work and long hours that
had been hallmarks of his practice of law, and he confessed that he was,
from time to time, sorely tempted to descend from the bench and join
in the fray.
Upon leaving the bar and taking his place as a district judge, he
said:
"I now say farewell to the practice of law I have loved so well. It is
a step that one does not contemplate lightly. Yet I do this willingly,
and I hope that there will be no change in me. If you have liked me
as a lawyer, then you should like me as a judge, for I shall not change.
The law has been my life. I wish every man who devotes his life to it
could love it as I do."

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1975
381
Justice Whittaker served on the Court of Appeals for only one year,
until March 3, 1957, when he was nominated as an Associate Justice
of this Court by President Eisenhower. His nomination was hailed by
the public and the profession alike, and he was quickly confirmed by
the Senate.
He served as an Associate Justice for five years, from 1957 through
1962. During his service on this Court, he wrote 42 majority opinions
and 50 concurring or dissenting opinions.
By training and inclination, his primary interest lay in the field of
commercial law, as is shown by his opinions involving complex tax
issues, such as Turnbow v. Commissioner, and Allied Stores of Ohio v.
Bowers; and in difficult patent cases, such as Aro Manufacturing Com-
pany v. Convertible Top Replacement Company.
His work was not, of course, limited to issues of commercial law or
taxation, and his opinions concerning matters of constitutional law
are found in such decisions as Staub v. City of Baxley, which held a
local ordinance regulating permits for solicitation of membership in
organizations violative of the First Amendment; and Payne v.
Arkansas, which dealt with coerced confessions in criminal cases; and
McNeal v. Culver, concerning the right to counsel.
In the spring of 1962, Mr. Justice Whittaker was advised by his
physician that his health would be endangered if he continued to serve
on this Court. Bowing to that advice, he submitted his resignation
on March 30, 1962, which was acknowledged by the Chief Justice and
his Associate Justices with deep regret.
After his resignation from the Court, he returned to Kansas City.
And in the 2 years following his resignation, he worked actively for
the American Bar Association and also served as a member of the
American Medical Association's commission for the in-depth study
of post-graduate medical education. He contributed his time and his
efforts to several civic and charitable enterprises in the Kansas City
area, including the Kansas City Hospital.
In 1965, he became an arbitrator on behalf of the General Motors
Corporation and was engaged in deciding controversies between that
firm and its dealers.
To the end of his life, Mr. Justice Whittaker continued a deep
interest in the law and in the contribution that courts and lawyers.
can make to the resolution of social conflict by litigation or arbitration.
He frequently expressed his concern about what he perceived to be
an increasing tendency in our society to resort to political or eco-
nomic pressures rather than to the methods of dispute settlements
established by the legal system.
Wherefore, it is resolved that we, the Bar of the Supreme Court
of the United States, express our profound sorrow at the death of

382
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1975
Justice Charles Evans Whittaker, and our grateful appreciation for
his long years of service in the judicial branch of his national gov-
ernment, and in civil life, culminating with his work as a Justice
of the Supreme Court.
And it is further resolved that the Solicitor General be asked
to present these resolutions to the Court with the prayer that they
be embodied in its permanent records and that copies of these resolu-
tions be forwarded to the widow and to the children of Justice
Whittaker.
The Chief Justice said:
"Thank you, Mr. Solicitor General, your motion will be granted.
I recognize the Attorney General of the United States."
Mr. Attorney General Levi addressed the Court as follows:
"Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:
"The Bar of this Court met today to honor the memory of Charles
Evans Whittaker, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court from
1957 to 1962.
Mr. Justice Whittaker's appointment to this Court on March 3,
1957, was the culmination of a distinguished professional career. He
came to this Court with not only an outstanding reputation at the
bar gained as a leading trial lawyer in Kansas City, but also with
prior judicial experience from his service as both a federal dis-
trict judge in the Western District of Missouri and as a judge of
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Indeed,
he was one of the few members of this Court to have served at every
level of the federal judiciary.
Although his opinions covered the full range of the subject matter
jurisdiction of this Court, Justice Whittaker's primary interest, due
no doubt to his experience at the practicing bar, was in the area of
commercial law. During his tenure as an Associate Justice, he authored
many of this Court's decisions involving federal and State taxation.
In Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company v. Bowers, for example, he
dealt with the subtleties and intricacies of State power of taxation,
measured against the Import-Export Clause, reconciling their com-
peting demands in an opinion for the Court that remains the lead-
ing exposition of that complex subject.
Justice Whittaker drew on his experience as a trial lawyer and
as a district judge in dealing with several important questions of
federal jurisdiction. In Florida Lime and Avocado Growers v. Jacob-
sen, he thoroughly canvassed the legislative history of statutory
provisions and judicial precedent regarding three-judge courts, and in
Hoffman v. Blaski, he provided authoritative guidance for federal
trial judges concerning the transfer of venue provisions of 28 USC
1404. His most significant opinion in this area, and perhaps his most
significant opinion as a member of this Court, was Leedom v. Kyne,

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1975
383
in which he carefully analyzed the relevant provisions of the National
Labor Relations Act in Title 28 of the United States Code, in sustain-
ing the jurisdiction of federal district courts to entertain suits chal-
lenging ultra vires actions of the Labor Board.
He brought similar penetration, rigor, and respect for the rule of
law to bear in his opinions in Klein, the constitutional safeguards of
liberties to challenged governmental action. In one of his most mem-
orable opinions for the Court, Staub v. City of Baxley, he found
constitutionally invalid a city ordinance requiring a permit for solicit-
ing membership in any organization requiring fees or dues from its
members, in giving the Mayor and City Council uncontrolled discre-
tion to grant or deny such a permit. He wrote for the Court that in
thus making, "the enjoyment of speech contingent upon the will of
the mayor and council of the city, such an ordinance imposes an
unconstitutional prior restraint on the enjoyment of First Amend-
ment freedoms."
Whatever the issue involved, Mr. Justice Whittaker's opinions were
marked by a degree of care and precision that reflected his view that
the law was a calling to hard work, and he once observed that justice.
cannot be produced through any system of procedures alone; in the
main, it must always be the product of long hours of hard, diligent,
painstaking labor by highly competent, experienced, careful and prac-
tical lawyers.
Throughout his career, as both a lawyer and a judge, Mr. Justice
Whittaker adhered to those principles and combined them with a
spirit of cooperation and good will. While always showing esteem for
his brethren on the Court, and sincere respect for their work, he did.
not hesitate to take telling issue on occasions with what he regarded
as analytical shortcomings in the Court's opinions. Examples of this
are his dissenting opinion in James v. United States, analyzing power-
fully and lucidly the tax consequences of embezzlement, illuminating
the basic concept of taxable income, and his concurring opinion in
Gomillion v. Lightfoot, dealing succinctly with the relationship be-
tween the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendment claims in that case.
On the occasion of his resignation from this Court, compelled
by his physician's advice, his brethren on this Court, in acknowledging
his departure with regret, wrote to him:
"Our five years of association with you have been in the finest
traditions of the Court, no Justice could have worked harder or in
more complete harmony with his brethren."
As a personal matter, I hope it is appropriate for me to note that
over a two-year period I served with Justice Whittaker on a citizens
commission which explored in considerable depth the problems of
graduate medical education. This was a matter of considerable interest
to Justice Whittaker, and he brought to the work of the commission

384
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1975
his extraordinary powers of analysis and his determination to think
through the very difficult issues of policy. Working with Justice
Whittaker during this period was a rare experience, which I greatly
value.
I will close with the tribute paid to Mr. Justice Whittaker in the
letter from Phineas Rosenberg of the Kansas City Bar to the Solicitor
General. Mr. Rosenberg wrote:
"My close friendship with Mr. Justice Whittaker began in the
early days of our respective lives and continued for years until his
death. Thus, you can know and understand that my heart is full of
fondest memories of him, which I shall always cherish, of a great
love and admiration of him as a great lawyer, an outstanding jurist,
and a man having the highest concept of honor and integrity, whose
aim in life was to do justice fairly and impartially, and of respect for
his high standards of patriotism. No man had a greater or more un-
restrained love for his country."
May it please this honorable Court, in the name of the lawyers of
this nation and particularly for the Bar of this Court, I respectfully
request that the resolution presented to you in memory of the late
Justice Charles Evans Whittaker be accepted by you and that it, to-
gether with a chronicle of these proceedings, be ordered kept for all
time in the records of this Court."
The Chief Justice said:
"Your motion is granted, Mr. Attorney General, and we thank you
for these statements and tributes of the Supreme Court Bar to our
late brother, Charles Evens Whittaker.
These presentations made here today in his memory will be made
a permanent part of the records of this Court, and we ask you to
convey to the Chairman and the other members of the Committee on
Resolutions our appreciation for their presentation today.
We accept these memorial tributes to Mr. Justice Whittaker made
by you, Mr. Attorney General, and you, Mr. Solicitor General, on
behalf of the Memorial Committee.
You have appropriately paid tribute to Justice Whittaker as a
self-made lawyer who became one of the foremost advocates of his
bar and whose talents were sought by many clients during his years
of private practice.
His high standing as a lawyer was acknowledged by his peers, as
you have already noted, by his election to various offices in the
organized bar.
Of the 100 men who have come to this Court, including the nine
who now hold office, Justice Whittaker was unique in the sense that
his professional career covered the entire spectrum of the practice

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1975
385
of law and, in addition, he sat as a judge in all three tiers of the
federal bench.
Those who sat with him could understand readily why he achieved
great success at the bar. He was a perfectionist, with a passion for
the facts of the case, both when he was an advocate and when he was
a judge. And he was never content after he became a judge, until
he had mastered the facts of the case and, in his appellate work, until
he mastered the record.
He drove himself unsparingly in his dedication to achieve that
mastery, beginning with the petition or the jurisdictional statement
and continuing on through to the consideration of the case on the
merits.
Those who sat with him agree that he had few peers in terms of
profound and conscientious application to his daily work. Indeed,
he carried this to a point that was a source of concern to his friends
and to his family, as the work of the Court mounted after he reached
this Court.
His cheerful aspect in the private exchanges with his colleagues
and with members of the bar marked him as a man with a zest for life,
and particularly for the day-to-day interchange and discussion of
points of law.
His colleagues on each of the courts where he served saw him, and
here I use the words of one of the Eighth Circuit judges, "Charles
Whittaker was a good man", and he used this in the sense of the
innate decency and the firm adherence to high ideals in both his private
life and in his public duties.
Few men ever worked more diligently to search out every phase of
the questions which were brought to the Court, and his opinions on
this Court reflect scrupulous attention to details and comprehensive
treatment of all the relevant authorities. He had a firm belief that
the Court should not only reach a correct result, but that it had an
obligation to demonstrate how that result was reached.
His colleagues at the bar, his colleagues on the United States Dis-
trict Court, his colleagues on the United States Court of Appeals, and
the Justices of this Court, and of course his family and his close
associates can appropriately take great pride in his splendid career
as a lawyer and as a jurist."
Adjourned until Monday, February 24, 1975, at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1975

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-594. Martin O. Weisbrod, appellant, v. James T. Lynn,
Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument. The motion of The American Medi-
cal Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 74-767. Showdie Chu, appellant, v. United States. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 74-813. George J. Abraham and Larry Edward Zarsky, ap-
pellants, v. Florida et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-38. In the Matter of Disbarment of John J. Donnelly, Jr.
It is ordered that John J. Donnelly, Jr., of Geneva, Florida,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
matter.
No. D-39. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harvey Rosenberg. It is
ordered that Harvey Rosenberg, of Silver Spring, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1975
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
matter.
No. D-40. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald E. Gilbert. It is
ordered that Donald E. Gilbert, of East Northport, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
matter.
No. D-41. In the Matter of Disbarment of George J. Siegel. It is
ordered that George J. Siegel, of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr. Justice Marshall
took no part in the consideration or decision of this matter.
No. D-42. In the Matter of Disbarment of John W. Dean, III. It
is ordered that John W. Dean, III, of Los Angeles, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
matter.
No. D-43. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter C. Andresen. It is
ordered that Peter C. Andresen, of Kensington, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
matter.
No. 73-1573. Harold Withrow et al., etc., appellants, v. Duane
Larkin. The motion of the appellee for leave to file a supplemental
brief, after argument, is granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 73–1966. Aberdeen and Rockfish Railroad Company et al.,
appellants, v. Students Challenging Regulatory Agency Procedures
(SCRAP), et al.; and
No. 73-1971. United States et al., appellants, v. Students Chal-
lenging Regulatory Agency Procedures (SCRAP), et al. The joint
motion of the appellants for additional time for oral argument is
granted and ten additional minutes are granted each side. Mr. Justice
Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 73–6336. George Herman Rogers, petitioner, ". United States.
The motion of the petitioner for the appointment of counsel is granted,

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1975
391
and it is ordered that Ralph W. Parnell, Jr., Esquire, of Shreveport,
Louisiana, be, and he is hereby appointed to serve as counsel for the
petitioner in this case. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No. 73–6587. Clifford Herring, appellant, v. New York. The mo-
tion of the Attorney General of New York to permit two counsel to
argue orally on behalf of the State of New York is granted. Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 73-7031. Jesse Thurman Fowler, petitioner. v. North Caro-
lina. The motion of the Attorney General of California for additional
time to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 74–8. J. B. O'Connor, petitioner, . Kenneth Donaldson. The
motion of the respondent for leave to file a supplemental brief, after
argument, is granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-70. Lewis H. Goldfarb et al., petitioners, v. Virginia State
Bar et al. The motion of the District of Columbia Bar for reconsidera-
tion of the motion for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.
The motion of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York
for reconsideration of the motion for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, is granted and it is ordered that the brief be filed. Mr. Justice
Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of these motions.
No. 74–124. Blue Chip Stamps et al., petitioners, v. Manor Drug
Stores, etc. The motion of the Solicitor General for additional time to
permit the Securities and Exchange Commission to participate in oral
argument, as amicus curiae, is denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-389. Albemarle Paper Company et al., petitioners, v.
Joseph P. Moody et al.; and
No. 74-428. Halifax Local No. 425, United Papermakers and
Paperworkers, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Joseph P. Moody et al. The
motion of the American Society for Personnel Administration for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice Marshall
and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision
of this motion.
No. 74-6019. Sandra Steel, petitioner, v. The Supreme Court of
Colorado et al. The motion to expedite consideration is denied. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.

cuit granted.

senting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stew-
art and Mr. Justice Marshall join.

Institution, etc., petitioner, v. William Matthews. Motion of respon-

of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit denied.

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 74-717. James H. Herman, Andrew R. Chaja and Donald
Lowe, petitioners, v. Arkansas. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Arkansas denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall
join.

et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would
grant certiorari.

No. 74-5619. Pasquale Falcone, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

Blackmun would grant certiorari.

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Mexico denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.

wood et al. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision
of the cases in which orders or judgments in unargued cases are this
day announced with the exception of No. 74-5281-Spross v. Gunn,
No. 71-5435 Imbler v. Pachtman and No. 74-5466-Vigil v. New
Mexico.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court.
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit during the period of May 12 to May
15, 1975, and for such additional time as may be required to complete
unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294(a) is ordered entered
on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.C.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, March 3, 1975, until
Monday, March 17, 1975.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. Two hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by
Mr. Oliver P. Stockwell and Mr. Frederick W. Ellis for the defend-
ants and by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne for the plaintiff.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Justice Marshall is absent but reserves the right to participate
in today's argument in No. 35 Original on the basis of the entire rec-
ord, briefs, and the tape recording of the oral argument.

402
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1975
No. 35, Original. United States. plaintiff. v. State of Maine et al.
Three hours allowed for oral argument. Argument commenced by
Mr. Brice M. Clagett for the defendants and continued by Mr. Solici-
tor General Bork for the plaintiff.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1975
403
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
OPINIONS
No. 73–1513. United States, petitioner, v. Ronald S. Jenkins. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist. Statement by Mr. Justice Douglas concurring in the affirmance
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 73–1395. United States, petitioner, v. George J. Wilson, Jr.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals to consider the merits of the Government's appeal. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 73-1285. John P. Wood et al., petitioners, v. Peggy Strickland,
a minor, by Mr. and Mrs. Virgil Justice, her parents and next friends,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
join.
No. 73-1279. The Williams and Wilkins Company, petitioner, v.
United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Claims. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion
per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 73–1471. United States et al., petitioners, v. New Jersey State
Lottery Commission. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam announced
by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Mr. Chief Justice Burger took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this case.
580-278-75-51
.

;
· TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1975
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 35, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Maine et al.
Argument concluded by Mr. Brice M. Clagett for the defendants.
No. 52, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Florida. One and one half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued
by Mr. Keith A. Jones for the plaintiff and by Mr. Robert L. Shevin
for the defendant.
No. 73-6033. Sharon Roe et al., appellants, v. Nicholas Norton,
etc. One hour and twenty minutes allowed for oral argument. Argued
by Mr. Frank Cochran for the parent appellants, by Mr. David N.
Rosen for the children appellants and by Mr. Michael Anthony
Arcari for the appellee. Supplemental memoranda to come.
No. 73-1995. Allen F. Breed, etc., petitioner, v. Gary Steven
Jones. Argument commenced by Mr. Russell Iungerich for the pe-
titioner and continued by Mr. Robert L. Walker for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1975
405
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73-1995. Allen F. Breed, etc., petitioner, v. Gary Steven
Jones. Argument concluded by Mr. Robert L. Walker for the
respondent.
No. 73-1942. Richard Erznoznik, etc., appellant, v. City of Jack-
sonville. Argued by Mr. William H. Maness for the appellant and
by Mr. William Lee Allen for the appellee.
No. 73-1531. Albert Johnson et al., petitioners, v. Mississippi et al.
Argued by Mr. Frank R. Parker for the petitioners and by Mr. Ed
Davis Noble, Jr., for the respondents.
No. 73-6587. Clifford Herring, appellant, v. New York. Argued
by Miss Diana A. Steele for the appellant and by Mr. Norman C.
Morse and Mr. Gabriel I. Levy for the appellee.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 74–1062. James Caldwell, petitioner, v. City of New Orleans.
The application for stay of execution and enforcement of sentence,
presented to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred to the Court,
is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this application.
Adjourned until Monday, March 3, 1975, at 10 o'clock.

Appeal from the United States
