(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1975
407
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-6980. James Edward Swigert et al., appellants, v. Paul
A. Miller et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio. Hamilton
County. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Ohio,
Hamilton County, for further consideration in light of Wood v. Strick-
land, U.S. (1975). Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion and case.
-
-
No. 74–552. J. Paul Jewell et al., appellants, v. Robert Docking
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Kansas. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-682. Crete Carrier Corp., appellant, v. United States et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Nebraska. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-794. Leahn J. Halprin et al., appellants, v. California
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appel-
late District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereupon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-885. John H. Sununu, Elsie Vartanian and R. Patrick Cor-
bin, appellants, v. Robert L. Stark, Secretary of State of New Hamp-
shire. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Mark Trail Camp Grounds, Inc., petitioner, v. Field
Enterprises, Inc. The motion of the petitioner to reconsider the denial
of motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
580-278-75-53

408
MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1975
No. A-664. Adolf Harold Marks, applicant, v. Florida. The ap-
plication for stay of execution and enforcement of sentence, presented
to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice Marshall would
grant the application. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this application.
No. A-676. United States, applicant, v. Missouri et al. The applica-
tion to vacate the stay heretofore entered by the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun
and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. 66, Original. Robert L. Montgomery, plaintiff, v. Congress of
the United States et al. The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint
and for all other relief is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 73-1046. Casper W. Weinberger, Secretary of the Depart-
ment of Health, Education and Welfare, appellant, v. Santiago Diaz
et al.; and
No. 73-1596. Robert E. Hampton, Chairman of the United States
Civil Service Commission et al., petitioners, v. Mow Sun Wong et al.
These cases are restored to the calendar for reargument. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 73–1820. Paul R. Philbrook, etc., appellant, v. Jean Glodgett
et al.; and
No. 74-132. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Edu-
cation and Welfare, appellant, v. Jean Glodgett et al. The motion of
appellants for divided argument is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74–124. Blue Chip Stamps et al., petitioners, v. Manor Drug
Stores, etc. The motion of respondent for divided argument is granted.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
No. 74-1015. Intercounty Construction Corporation et al., peti-
tioners, v. Noah C. A. Walter, etc., et al.; and
No. 74–1031. Wallace L. Files, petitioner, v. Edgar F. Heiskell,
III, Secretary of State of West Virginia, et al. The motions to ex-
pedite consideration are denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in
the consideration or decision of these motions.
CERTIORARI DENIED

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit denied.

Texas. Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of mandamus denied.

these motions.

Paul M. Stewart,
Jr.
OPINIONS
No. 73-938. Cox Broadcasting Corporation et al., appellants, v.
Martin Cohn. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Georgia for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurs in
the judgment. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 73-1380. Chemehuevi Tribe of Indians et al., petitioners, v.
Federal Power Commission et al.;
No. 73-1666. Arizona Public Service Company et al., petitioners,
v. Chemehuevi Tribe of Indians et al.; and
No. 73–1667. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Cheme-
huevi Tribe of Indians et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the District of Columbia Circuit with directions to enter a judg-
ment affirming the Commission's dismissal of the complaint for lack of
jurisdiction. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 73-1148. Cheryl Spider DeCoteau, natural mother and next
friend of Robert Lee Feather and Herbert John Spider, etc., peti-
tioner, v. The District County Court for the Tenth Judicial District.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Dakota; and
No. 73-1500. Don R. Erickson, Warden, petitioner, v. John Lee
Feather et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment in No. 74-1148 affirmed.

MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1975
421
Judgment in No. 73-1500 reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall join.
No. 73-1424. David Emery Serfass, petitioner, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Bur-
ger. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 73-820. United States, petitioner, v. Pascual Guana-Sanchez.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently
granted. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 74-5140. Michael J. Cassius, petitioner, v. Arizona. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Writ of certiorari
dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice
Powell dissent. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, March 17, 1975, at 10 o'clock.

k

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1975
423
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 74-479. W. J. Estelle, Jr., Director, Texas Department of
Corrections, petitioner, v. Jerry Mack Dorrough. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-515. B-H Transfer Co., appellant, v. United States and
Interstate Commerce Commission. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Georgia. Motion of the
American Short Line Railroad Association for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-664. Michael Silvers, appellant, v. Clarence Dowling,
Judge, Civil District Court, Orleans Parish, Louisiana, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-684. Frithjof O. M. Westby, etc., et al., appellants, v. Jane
Doe, etc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of South Dakota. Motion of the National Black Feminist
Organization et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the District of South Dakota for further consideration in
light of Hagans v. Lavine, 415 U.S. 528, 543–545 (1974).
580-278-75--54

424
MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1975
No. 74-780. Adrian Clyde Humphreys, III, et al., appellants, v.
Ellen M. Coxeter Humphreys et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 74-924. United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company, ap-
pellant, v. City of Spartanburg and the Treasurer of said City.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Carolina. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Thomas Martin Austin et al., petitioners, v. United States
et al. The motion of the petitioners for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied.
No. A–697. Raymond G. DeChamplain, applicant, v. Hewitt E.
Lovelace, Jr., et al. The application for bail, presented to Mr. Justice
Stewart and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart would grant the application.
No. A-721. United States Steel Corporation, applicant, v. Jimmie
L. Rodgers et al. The order heretofore entered on March 5, 1975, by
Mr. Justice Brennan is vacated and the application for recall and
stay of the mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit is denied.
No. A-725. First American Bank & Trust Company et al., appli-
cants, v. G. W. Ellwein et al. The application for stay pending ap-
peal, presented to Mr. Justice White and by him referred to the Court,
is denied.
No. 73-1869. Peter H. Beer et al., appellants, v. United States
et al. The motion of the appellees for divided argument is granted.
No. 73–1908. Stewart S. Cort et al., petitioners, v. Richard A. Ash,
etc. The motion of Common Cause for reconsideration of the motion
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73-7031. Jesse Thurman Fowler, petitioner, v. North Carolina.
The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral ar-
gument. as amicus curiae, is granted and fifteen minutes are allotted
for that purpose. The petitioner is allotted fifteen additional minutes
for oral argument.,
No. 74-22. Ivan Allen Company, petitioner, v. United States. The
motion of the American Trading and Production Corporation for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae. is granted.
No. 74-363. United States, petitioner, v. Reliable Transfer Co.,
Inc. The motion of the Solicitor General to permit John P. Rupp.
Esquire, to present oral argument, pro hac vice, on behalf of the
United States is granted.
No. 74-878. The National League of Cities et al., appellants, v.
Peter J. Brennan, Secretary of Labor; and

.

MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1975
425
No. 74-879. California, appellant, v. Peter J. Brennan, Secretary
of Labor. The motion of the appellants for additional time for oral
argument is granted and thirty additional minutes are allotted for
that purpose. The appellee is allotted thirty additional minutes for
oral argument.
No. 74–1056. Joseph Bernard Droback, petitioner, v. United
States. The application for bail, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and
by him referred to the Court, is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED

this case probable jurisdiction noted.

Family Services, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Illinois. Motion of appellants for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case probable jurisdic-
tion noted.

OPINIONS
No. 35, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Maine et al.
On Exceptions to Report of the Special Master. Judgment entered
for the United States. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. On Exceptions to Report of the Special Master.
Recommendations contained in Report of Special Master accepted
and parties directed to file a decree. Opinion per curiam announced
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 52, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Florida. On Exceptions to Report of the Special Master. Exceptions
of the State of Florida overruled. Exceptions of the United States
referred to the Special Master. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr.

MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1975
441
Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73-1701. United States, appellant, v. National Association
of Securities Dealers, Inc., et al. One and one half hours allowed for
oral argument. Argued by Mr. Gerald P. Norton for the appellant,
by Mr. Lee Loevinger for the appellees, and by Mr. Walter P. North
for the Securities and Exchange Commission, as amicus curiae, by
special leave of Court.
No. 73–2024. Robert Warth, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Ira Seldin
et al. Argued by Mrs. Emmelyn Logan-Baldwin for the petitioners and
by Mr. James M. Hartman for the respondents.
No. 73–6739. Steven Costarelli, appellant, v. Massachusetts. Ar-
gued by Mr. Robert W. Hagopian for the appellant and by Mr. David
A. Mills for the appellee. Memorandum to come.
No. 73-2055. Securities Investor Protection Corporation, peti-
tioner, v. James C. Barbour et al. Argument commenced by Mr. Wil-
fred R. Caron for the petitioner.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

TUESDAY, MARCH 18, 1975
443
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice

OPINIONS
No. 73–296. Lawrence S. Huffman, etc., et al., appellants, v.
Pursue, Ltd. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Ohio. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall
join.
No. 73-1541. Robert Reid and Nadia Alice Reid, petitioners, v.
Immigration and Naturalization Service. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 73-1708. Kevin J. Burns, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Linda
Alcala et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 73–1004. Southeastern Promotions, Ltd., petitioner, v. Steve
Conrad et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissent-
580-278-75--56

444
TUESDAY, MARCH 18, 1975
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
White with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

tioner, v. James C. Barbour et al. Argument continued by Mr. Wilfred

for the respondents.

No. 73–1123. United States, petitioner, v. Ralph Feola. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment with respect to the respondent's conspiracy con-
viction reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins.

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oregon. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Oregon for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Hampshire. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of New Hampshire
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 74-751. James D. Cox, Former Assistant Director for Treat-
ment, Virginia Division of Corrections, et al., petitioners, v. James
R. Cook. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-374. The Times-Picayune Publishing Corporation, appel-
lant v. Oliver P. Schulingkamp. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed as moot.
No. 74-919. Rex John Crookshanks, appellant, v. Marta Anna
Crookshanks. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second
Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 74-977. Joseph S. Rosenthal, appellant, v. Board of Education
of Central High School District No. 3 of Town of Hempstead, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern Dis-
trict of New York. Judgment affirmed.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-687. Hewitt E. Lovelace, Jr., et al., applicants, v. Raymond
G. DeChamplain. The application for a further stay of the order of
the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri,
presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court,
is granted pending the filing on or before April 10, 1975, of a petition
for a writ of certiorari and final disposition thereon. Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would deny
580-278-75-58

448
MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1975
the application except upon condition that the respondent be released
on bail.
No. D-27. In the Matter of Disbarment of Francis X. McDermott.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-34. In the Matter of Disbarment of Elaine Worley Kerr.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-35. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas Paul Raimondi.
Thomas Paul Raimondi, of Baltimore, Maryland, having requested
to resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that
his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice
before the Bar of this Court. The rule to show cause heretofore issued
on January 20, 1975, is hereby discharged.
No. D-44. In the Matter of Disbarment of Edward LeRoy Morgan.
It is ordered that Edward LeRoy Morgan, of Phoenix, Arizona, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 73–6739. Steven Costarelli, appellant, v. Massachusetts. The
motion of the Massachusetts Defenders Committee for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 74–157. United Housing Foundation, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
Milton Forman et al.; and
No. 74–647. State of New York and the New York State Housing
Finance Agency, petitioners, v. Milton Forman et al. The motion of
the petitioners for additional time for oral argument is granted and
ten additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. The respondents
are allotted ten additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 74-389. Albemarle Paper Company et al., petitioners, v.
Joseph P. Moody et al.; and
No. 74-428. Halifax Local No. 425, United Papermakers and Pa-
perworkers, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Joseph P. Moody et al. The mo-
tion of the petitioners for additional time for oral argument is granted
and ten additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. The re-
spondents are allotted ten additional minutes for oral argument. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 74-511. James Trainor, Acting Director, Illinois Department
of Public Aid, petitioner, v. Elvira Vargas, etc. The motion for leave
to supplement the petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
No. 74-1169. David Rogers et al., appellants, v. Inmates' Coun-
cilmatic Voice et al. The application for stay of execution of para-
graph seven of the order of the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Ohio, presented to Mr. Justice Stewart and by

him referred to the Court, is granted pending final disposition of

LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 74-6101. Harry Theriault, petitioner, v. Virgil Pittman,
Chief Judge, et al. Motion for leave to file petition writ of habeas
corpus and/or mandamus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 74-5988. Ervin Hohensee, petitioner, v. Malcolm Muir, Judge,
U.S. District Court, Middle District of Pennsylvania. Motion for leave
to file petition for writ of mandamus denied.
No. 74–5823. Walter Martin. Jr., petitioner, v. United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Motion for leave to file peti-
tion for writ of mandamus and/or prohibition denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 74-5436. Theodore J. Horne, Jr., petitioner, v. United States;
and
No. 74-5816. William Brady Trigg, petitioner, v. Tennessee. Peti-
tions for rehearing denied.
No. 74-5529. Vera M. Mchar, petitioner, v. Joseph McHale. Mo-
tion for leave to file petition for rehearing denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
the cases in which orders or judgments in unargued cases are this day
announced except Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdic-
tion and set No. 74-374-Times-Picayune Publishing Corp. v.
Schulingkamp for oral argument and would grant certiorari in the

457
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties and sit on a panel in the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit to hear the
following cases:
Hartman v. Switzer et al. (No. 74–1861).
Hartman v. United States et al. (No. 74-1881).
Hartman and Daly v. Tannenwald, et al. (No. 74–1882).

Edward A. Cupp v. Secretary of the Treasury, etc. (No. 73–
1837).
Edward A. Cupp v. William Saxbe et al. (No. 74–2147).
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on the minutes of
this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit during the period beginning June
9, 1975, and ending June 13, 1975, and for such additional time as may
be required to complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
§ 294(a) is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to
28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, March 31, 1975, until
Monday, April 14, 1975.

OPINIONS
No. 73-662. James R. Schlesinger et al., petitioners, v. Bruce R.
Councilman. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Statement
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan concurring and dissenting with whom Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 73-64. Robert E. Iannelli et al., petitioners, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join in Part II of the opinion.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.

ley, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Alabama. Order vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama
so that a fresh order may be entered and a timely appeal prosecuted to

the Court of Appeals. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.

The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-743. Comet Electronics, Inc., et al., appellants, v. United
States et al.;
No. 74-762. George T. Cook Company, Inc., et al., appellants, v.
United States et al.; and
No. 74-833. Trans-Mark Services, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Inter-
state Commerce Commission et al. Appeals from the United States
District Court for the Western District of Missouri. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 74-823. Servitron, Inc. and Alfred E. Smith, appellants, v.
Interstate Commerce Commission and United States. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana.
Judgment affirmed.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1763. William L. Lukhard, etc., petitioner, v. Jane Doe,
etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit;
No. 74-242. Thomas L. Hooker, Individually and as Director of
the New Hampshire Division of Welfare, petitioner, v. Arlene L.
Carver et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit; and
No. 74-637. James L. Trainor, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Sylvia
Wilson, etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motions of respondents for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petitions for writs of
certiorari granted, judgments vacated and cases remanded to the re-
spective United States Courts of Appeals for further consideration in
light of Burns v. Alcala, 420 U.S. — (1975).

v. Daniel Perez Echeverria. On petition for writ of certiorari to the

MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1975

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-232. Minnesota et al., applicants, v. Reserve Mining Com-
pany et al.; and
No. A-262. United States et al., applicants, v. Reserve Mining
Company et al. The renewed applications to vacate the indefinite stay
order pending appeal, presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun and by him
referred to the Court, are denied.
No. A-684. Glenn Maroe, applicant, v. Raymond Procunier et al.
The application for bail, presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-697. Raymond G. DeChamplain, applicant, v. Hewitt E.
Lovelace, Jr., et al. The reapplication for bail, presented to Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-728. B. Coleman Corporation et al., applicants, v. Daniel J.
Walker et al. The application for a stay or for an injunction, presented
to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-765. William K. Patterson et al., applicants, v. Superior
Court of Calif., County of Fresno, et al. The application for a stay,
presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him referred to the Court, is
denied. The stay heretofore granted by Mr. Justice Douglas on March
21, 1975, is vacated. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the Court's
order vacating his previous stay.
No. D-45. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Newton Mitchell.
It is ordered that John Newton Mitchell, of New York, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr.
Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this
matter.
No. D-46. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Charles Mardian.
It is ordered that Robert Charles Mardian, of Phoenix, Arizona, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr.
Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this
matter.
No. 73-1888. United States, petitioner, v. Alaska. The motion of
the respondent for divided argument is granted.

MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1975
469
No. 74-362. Intercounty Construction Corporation et al., petition-
ers, v. Noah C. A. Walter, etc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor Gen-
eral to permit Frank H. Easterbrook, Esquire, to argue pro hac vice,
is granted.
No. 74-389. Albemarle Paper Company et al., petitioners, v.
Joseph P. Moody et al.; and

leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice Powell

No. 74-466. John T. Dunlop, Secretary of Labor, petitioner, v.
Walter Bachowski. The motion of the United Steelworkers of
America, AFL-CIO for additional time to present oral argument is
denied. The alternative request for divided argument is granted only
if the Solicitor General agrees to cede some of the time allotted the
petitioner for oral argument.
No. 74-634. United States v. Robert Lee Nobles. The motion of
the respondent for additional time for oral argument, or in the alter-
native for divided argument, is denied.
No. 74-878. The National League of Cities et al., appellants, v.
John T. Dunlop, Secretary of Labor; and
No. 74-879. California, appellant, v. John T. Dunlop, Secretary
of Labor. The motion of the Florida Police Benevolent Association
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 74-1185. Firestone Plastics Company et al., petitioners, v.
United States Department of Labor et al. The application for a stay,
presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the Court,
is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this application.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1975
479
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-497. BT Investment Managers, Inc., et al., appellants, v.
Fred O. Dickinson, Jr., Comptroller of the State of Florida, etc.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Florida. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Florida so that a
fresh order may be entered from which a timely appeal may be taken
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
No. 74-5850. Jessie N. Wicks, appellant, v. City of Charlottesville.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-6030. Robert Rivers, appellant, v. Virginia. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-6043. Thais Harris, appellant, v. City of Houston, Texas,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-2013. Edward Fair, Sheriff of Allen County, Ohio, peti-
tioner, v. Robert Smith and Otis Hatfield. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Cir-
cuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of Bellis v. United States, 417 U.S. 85 (1974).
580-278-75-62

480
•
MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1975
ORDER IN PENDING CASES
No. Lucian J. Rossi, etc., applicant, v. James Spector, etc.,
et al. The motion to dispense with printing the petition for writ of cer-
tiorari and for other relief is denied. Snider v. All State Administra-
tors, Inc., 414 U.S. 685 (1974).
No. A-1310, 1973 Term. Audubon Society, Los Angeles Chapter,
et al., applicants, v. Rogers C. B. Morton et al. The motion of the
County of Los Angeles to vacate the stay heretofore entered by Mr.
Justice Douglas on August 15, 1974, is granted.
No. A-789. National Right to Work Legal Defense and Educa-
tion Foundation, Inc., et al., applicants, v. Charles R. Richey, United
States District Court Judge for the District of Columbia. The appli-
cation for a stay of the disclosure order of the United States District
Court for the District of Columbia issued June 5, 1974, presented to
the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-818. Rafael Hernandez Colon, Governor of the Common-
wealth of Puerto Rico, et al., applicants, v. German Ortiz et al. The
application for stay of the judgment of the United States District
Court for the District of Puerto Rico, presented to Mr. Justice Bren-
nan and by him referred to the Court, is granted pending the timely
docketing of an appeal and final disposition thereon in this Court.
No. D-24. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael B. Nitsberg.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-25. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arthur Dale Leach. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-31. In the Matter of Disbarment of John A. Ross, Jr. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D--40. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald E. Gilbert. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-48. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Daniel Ehrlich-
man. It is ordered that John Daniel Ehrlichman, of Bellevue, Wash-
ington, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of
this matter.
No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana.
The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed. Excep-
tions, if any, with supporting briefs, to the Report may be filed by the
parties on or before May 29, 1975. Reply briefs, if any, to such excep-
tions may be filed on or before June 30, 1975.

MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1975
481
No. 73-776. James R. Schlesinger, Secretary of Defense, et al.
appellants, v. Robert C. Ballard. The motion of appellee to retax costs
is denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would grant the motion.
No. 73–1513. United States, petitioner, v. Ronald S. Jenkins.
The motion of the respondent for appointment of counsel, nunc pro
tunc, is granted, and it is ordered that James S. Carroll, Esquire, New
York, New York, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel
for the respondent in this case.
No. 74-80. George F. Kugler, Jr., etc., et al., petitioners, v. Edwin
H. Helfant; and
No. 74-277. Edwin H. Helfant, petitioner, v. George F. Kugler,
Jr., etc., et al. The motion to strike oral argument is denied.
No. 74–116. Diane M. Place, petitioner, v. Caspar W. Weinberger
et al. The Solicitor General is requested to file a response to the petition
for rehearing within thirty days.
No. 74–121. Craig Phelps, Receiver in Bankruptcy, petitioner,
v. United States. The motion to postpone oral argument is denied.
No. 74-175. J. William Middendorf, II, et al., petitioners, v.
Daniel Edward Henry et al.; and
No. 74-5176. Daniel Edward Henry et al., petitioners, v. J. Wil-
liam Middendorf, II, individually and in his capacity as Secretary
of the Navy, et al. These cases are restored to the calendar for reargu-
ment.
No. 74-450. Administrator, Federal Aviation Administration, et
al., petitioners, v. Reuben B. Robertson, III, et al. The motion of Mary
Helen Sears for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus
curiae, is denied.
No. 74-456. John Hill, Attorney General of Texas, et al., appel-
lants, v. Printing Industries of the Gulf Coast et al. The motion of
Common Cause for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus
curiae, is denied.
No. 74-676. W. J. Estelle, Jr., Director, Texas Department of
Corrections, petitioner, v. Harry Lee Williams. The motion of ap-
pointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that Ben L. Ader-
holt, Esquire of Houston, Texas, a member of the Bar of this Court,
be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent
in this case.
No. 74-878. The National League of Cities et al., appellants, v.
John T. Dunlop, Secretary of Labor; and
No. 74–879. California, appellant, v. John T. Dunlop, Secretary
of Labor. The motion of Harrison A. Williams, Jr. and Jacob Javits
for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.

482
MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1975
No. 74-882. Leonor Alberti DeCanas and Miguel Canas, peti-
tioners, v. Anthony G. Bica and Juan Silva. The Solicitor General
is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 74-928. United States, petitioner, v. Nathan George Dinitz.
The motion for appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered
that Fletcher H. Baldwin, Jr., Esquire, of Gainesville, Florida, a
member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 74-942. Frank L. Rizzo et al., petitioners, v. Gerald G. Goode
et al. The application to recall and stay the mandate of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, presented to the Chief
Justice, and by him referred to the Court, is granted pending final
disposition of the case in this Court.
No. 74-1164. Alfred A. Knopf, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. William
Colby, as Director of Central Intelligence of the United States, et al.
The motion to expedite consideration of the petition for certiorari is
denied.
No. 74-5116. Jack Roland Murphy, petitioner, v. Florida. The
motion of respondent to permit William L. Rogers, Esquire, to argue
pro hac vice, is granted.
No. 74-5566. Pearl Barrett, petitioner, v. United States. The mo-
tion for appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that
Thomas A. Schaffer, Esquire, of Cincinnati, Ohio, be, and he is
hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 74-775. City of New Orleans et al., appellants, v. Nancy
Dukes, dba Louisiana Concessions. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of appellee for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case further considera-
tion of the question of jurisdiction postponed to the hearing of the
case on the merits.
No. 74-858. Hugh L. Carey. Governor of the State of New York,
et al., appellants, v. Bert Randolph Sugar and Wrestling Revue, Inc.;
and
No. 74-859. Curtis Circulation Company and Continental Casual-
ty Company, appellants, v. Bert Randolph Sugar and Wrestling
Revue, Inc. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York. In these cases probable jurisdiction
noted. Cases consolidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral
argument.

MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1975
CERTIORARI GRANTED
483
No. 74-848. Bert A. David, Commander, Fort Dix Military
Reservation, et al., petitioners, v. Benjamin Spock et al. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit granted.
No. 74-891. Edgar Paul, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Edward Charles
Davis III. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted.
No. 74-944. Time, Inc., petitioner, v. Mary Alice Firestone.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida
granted.
No. 74–1042. Ernst & Ernst, petitioner, v. Olga Hochfelder et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit granted. The Solicitor General is invited to
file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.

No. 73-6336. George Herman Rogers, petitioner, v. United States.

Allan A. Tuttle for the respondent.
No. 74-339. Albemarle Paper Company et al., petitioners, v. Jo-
seph P. Moody et al.; and
No. 74-428. Halifax Local No. 425, United Papermakers and
Paperworkers, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Joseph P. Moody et al. One
hour and twenty minutes allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr.
Francis V. Lowden, Jr., for the petitioners in No. 74-389, by Mr.

Court.

for the respondent.

continued by Mr. Scott P. Crampton for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

of Columbia for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion

Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice.
Marshall join.

Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

Opinion by Mr. Justice White.

☑

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1975
507
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice.
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–1973. Art Theater Guild, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Clark L.
Ewing. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this appeal.
No. 74-985. S.S. & W., Inc., et al., appellants, v. City of Kansas
City, Missouri, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Missouri.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 74-992. William H. Seaver, County Judge, Pasco County,
Dade City, Florida, et al., appellants, v. Philip Joseph Wiegand. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 74–1070. Joseph J. Rey, Sr., appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Eighth Supreme Judicial Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-1078. Rudolf Gonzales, appellant, v. Larry D. Coughenour.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
New Mexico. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-5898. Hyman Cohen, appellant, v. Henry Marsh et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the District of Con-
necticut. Motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
580-278-75--66

508
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1975
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States.
District Court for the District of Connecticut for consideration of the
question of mootness. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion and appeal.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-857. William Bucolo, Ronald A. Simpson and James R.
Agut, petitioners, v. Florida. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Florida. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment reversed. Jenkins v. Georgia, 418 U.S. 153 (1974) and Kois
v. Wisconsin, 408 U.S. 229 (1972).
No. 74-877. Richard M. Harden, etc., petitioner, v. Ruth Parks,
etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of Burns v. Alcala, 420 U.S. (1975).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-
No. A-767. Lawrence E. Bowling, applicant, v. Charley Scott, In-
dividually and as Assistant Academic Vice President, Univesrity of
Alabama, et al. The reapplication for a stay and for other relief,
presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him referred to the Court,
is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of this reapplication.
No. D-47. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald W. Mayes. It is
ordered that Ronald W. Mayes, of Washington, D.C. and Madison,
Kansas, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision
of this matter.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of New Mexico.
The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is granted and the
defendant is allotted sixty days to answer. Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74–337. Frank Doran, etc., appellant, v. Salem Inn, Inc., et al.
The motion of the Town of Smithtown for leave to file an untimely
brief, as amicus curiae, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-364. United States, petitioner, v. William G. Hale. The
motion of respondent for appointment of counsel, nunc pro tunc, is
granted. It is ordered that Larry J. Ritchie, Esquire, of Washington,
D.C., be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the re-

MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1975
509
spondent in this case. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this motion.
No. 74–653. Michigan, petitioner, v. Richard Bert Mosley. The
motion of the Americans for Effective Law Enforcement, Inc., for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-1027. Genaro Garcia et al., appellants, v. The Texas State
Board of Medical Examiners and the Secretary of the State of Texas.
The motion to defer consideration of this appeal is granted. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74–1204. Sterling Keith Rogers, petitioner, v. United States.
The motion of the petitioner to expedite and to consolidate with No.
74-653, Michigan v. Mosley, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-6345. William Lee, petitioner, v. United States. The reap-
plication for a stay of mandate of the United States Court of Appeals.
for the Second Circuit, entered February 3, 1975, presented to Mr.
Justice Douglas and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice
Stewart would grant the stay. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this reapplication.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 74-1025. Burtice A. Hines et al., petitioners, v. Anchor Motor
Freight Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted limited to Question 1,
presented by the petition which reads as follows:
"1. Whether petitioners' claim under LMRA § 301 for wrongful
discharge is barred by the decision of a joint grievance committee up-
holding their discharge, notwithstanding that their union breached
its duty of fair representation in processing their grievance so as to
deprive them and the grievance committee of overwhelming evidence
of their innocence of the alleged dishonesty for which they were dis-
charged." Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this petition.
No. 74-5968. John A. Geders, petitioner, v. United States. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
granted limited to Question 1, presented by the petition which reads
as follows:
"1. Did the Court's order prohibiting defendant Geders and his
attorney from conferring with each other during a sixteen hour period
at a crucial stage of the trial deprive defendant Geders of his Sixth
Amendment right to assistance of counsel?" Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and petition.

510
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1975

liam L. Waller, individually and as Governor of the State of Missis-

this petition. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion and petition.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chef Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court.
of Appeals for the Second Circuit for the period June 2 and 3, 1975,
and for such additional time as may be required to complete unfinished
business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on the
minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

516
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1975
ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the term upon the conclusion of the arguments
in the cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 28, 1975, until
Monday, May 12, 1975.

ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTIONS

MONDAY, APRIL 28, 1975

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-238. National Liberty Life Insurance Company, appel-
lant, v. Wisconsin. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
This appeal having been made expressly contingent upon a grant of
certiorari in No. 74–193, and the petition for writ of certiorari in No.
74-193 having been denied today, the appeal is dismissed.
No. 74-793. Stanley Marks et al., appellants, v. Simon L. Leis,
Jr., etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Ohio. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio for
further consideration in light of Sosna v. Iowa, No. 73-762, n.3 (Janu-
ary 14, 1975), and Huffman v. Pursue, Ltd., No. 73-296 (March 18,
1975). Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice Marshall joins.
No. 74-1001. National Broadcasting Company, Inc., et al., ap-
pellants, v. United States. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Central District of California. The appeal is dismissed.
for want of jurisdiction. Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissents.
No. 74–1242. Custom Recording Company, Inc., etc., appellant,
e. Ray Blanton, Governor of Tennessee, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the Middle District of Tennessee so that a fresh order may be en-
tered from which a timely appeal may be taken to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. MTM Inc. v. Baxley, 420
U.S. (1975).
-

No. 73-1869. Peter H. Beer et al., appellants, v. United States
et al. This case is restored to the calendar for reargument.

Michael Allen Peters, Esquire, of Houston, Texas, be, and he is hereby,
appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 74–1047. Carla A. Hills, Secretary of Housing and Urban
Development, petitioner, v. Dorothy Gautreaux et al. The motion of
the Housing Authority of Elgin, Illinois, for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is denied.

Department of Labor, et al., appellants, v. Turner Elkhorn Mining
Company et al. The application for a stay of the order of the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky (C. A. No.
1761), entered on November 20, 1974, presented to Mr. Justice Stewart
and by him referred to the Court, is granted pending final disposition
of the appeal by this Court.
No. 74-5822. Charles Hampton, petitioner, v. United States. The
motion of appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that
David A. Lang, Esquire, of St. Louis, Missouri, be, and he is hereby,
appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.

No. 74-5793. Jose Franco Padilla, petitioner, v. New Mexico.
Motion for leave to file petition for rehearing denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
the cases in which orders or judgments in unargued cases are this day
announced with the exception of No. 74-903-Dyke v. Georgia.
Ordered:
ORDER
1. That the rules and forms as approved by the Judicial Conference
of the United States, to be known as the Chapter X Rules and Official
Chapter X Forms, be, and they hereby are, prescribed pursuant to Sec-
tion 2075, Title 28, United States Code, to govern the forms of process,
writs, pleadings and motions and the practice and procedure under
Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act, in the proceedings and to the extent
set forth therein, in the United States district courts, the District Court
for the District of the Canal Zone, and the District Courts of Guam
and the Virgin Islands.
'

534
MONDAY, APRIL 28, 1975
2. That the aforementioned Chapter X Rules and Official Chapter X
Forms shall take effect on August 1, 1975, and shall be applicable to
proceedings then pending except to the extent that in the opinion of
the court their application in a particular proceeding then pending
would not be feasible or would work injustice, in which event the
former procedure applies.
3. That General Order in Bankruptcy 52, heretofore prescribed by
this Court be, and it hereby is, abrogated, effective August 1, 1975.
4. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit the aforementioned new Chapter X Rules and Official Chap-
ter X Forms to the Congress in accordance with the provisions of
Title 28, U.S.C. § 2075.
ORDERED:
1. That the rules and forms as approved by the Judicial Conference
of the United States to be known as the Chapter XII Rules and Offi-
cial Chapter XII Forms, be, and they hereby are, prescribed pursuant
to Section 2075, Title 28, United States Code, to govern the forms of
process, writs, pleadings and motions and the practice and procedure
under Chapter XII of the Bankruptcy Act, in the proceedings and to
the extent set forth therein, in the United States district courts, the
District Court for the District of the Canal Zone, and the District
Courts of Guam and the Virgin Islands.
2. That the aforementioned Chapter XII Rules and Official Chap-
ter XII Forms shall take effect on August 1, 1975, and shall be appli-
cable to proceedings then pending except to the extent that in the
opinion of the court their application in a particular proceeding then
pending would not be feasible or would work injustice, in which event
the former procedure applies.
3. That General Orders in Bankruptcy Nos. 41 and 54 and Official
Forms in Bankruptcy Nos. 53 to 57 inclusive, heretofore prescribed
by this Court be, and they hereby are, abrogated, effective August 1,
1975.
4. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to trans-
mit the aforementioned new Chapter XII Rules and Official Chapter
XII Forms to the Congress in accordance with the provisions of Title
28, U. S. C. § 2075.
Mr. Justice Douglas, dissenting.
As I have said before, "I cannot agree to the Court's submission of
the proposed Bankrutcy Rules to the Congress." 411 U. S. 992 (1973).
I once knew a good deal about bankruptcy law, but I no longer have
the expertise to say whether the proposed rules are good or bad. Be-
cause this Court is no more than a "rubber stamp" I think it should
not participate in the rule-making process. The Judicial Conference
rather than this Court should send these rules to Congress if they
are to be sent at all.

MONDAY, APRIL 28, 1975
OPINIONS
No. 73-1233. National Labor Relations Board et al., petitioners,
v. Sears, Roebuck and Co. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed in part and reversed in part and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr. Chief Justice
Burger concurs in the judgment. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 73–1316. The Renegotiation Board, petitioner, v. Grumman
Aircraft Engineering Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-80. George F. Kugler, Jr., etc., et al., petitioners, v. Edwin
H. Helfant; and
No. 74-277. Edwin H. Helfant, petitioner, v. George F. Kugler,
Jr., etc., et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and cases remanded
to the Court of Appeals with directions to enter a judgment affirming
the District Court's dismissal of the complaint. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of these cases. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the de-
cision of these cases.
No. 73–1595. Colonial Pipeline Company, appellant, v. Joseph N.
Traigle, Collector of Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Louisiana. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice
Rehnquist joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr.
Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 73-6739. Steven Costarelli, appellant, v. Massachusetts.
Appeal from the Municipal Court of City of Boston, Massachusetts.
Appeal dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Opinion per curiam an-
nounced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, May 12, 1975, at 10 o'clock.
Х

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 12, 1975
541
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr.
Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74–691. Wilbur J. Schmidt, Secretary of the Wisconsin De-
partment of Health and Social Services, et al., appellants, v. Alberta
Lessard, etc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Wisconsin. Motion of appellee for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin
for further consideration in light of Huffman v. Pursue, Ltd., 420
U.S. (1975). Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion and appeal.
-
No. 74-912. Paul A. Stacy and Frank J. Kuhn, Jr., appellants,
v. Joan S. Mahan et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Virginia. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-1029. Chicago & Eastern Illinois Railroad Company et al.,
appellants, v. United States et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-1210. Robert E. Sadlak, appellant, v. John J. Gilligan et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Ohio. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-952. Ray Blanton, Governor of Tennessee, et al., appel-
lants, v. Americans United for the Separation of Church and State
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle Dis-
trict of Tennessee. The Court, being advised that after probable juris-
diction herein was noted on March 24, 1975, 420 U.S. — (1975),
the State's Tuition Grant statutory program was amended, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Middle District of Tennessee for reconsideration in light of the stat-
utory changes effected since the litigation was instituted. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
580-278-75-70

542
MONDAY, MAY 12, 1975
No. 74-955. Art Theater Guild, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Ohio
ex rel. James M. Schoen; and
No. 74-956. Art Theater Guild, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Ohio
ex rel. Robert J. Anderson. Appeals from the Court of Appeals of
Ohio, Lucas County. The appeals are dismissed for failure to file the
notices of appeal within the time provided by Rule 11 and 28 U.S.C.
§ 2101 (c).
No. 74-989. United States Clay Producers Traffic Association, Inc.,
et al., appellants, v. Central of Georgia Railroad Company et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the District of Colum-
bia. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 74-1158. Scott Smart, appellant, v. Texas Power & Light Com-
pany et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Texas. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas
so that a fresh order may be entered from which a timely appeal may
be taken to the United States Court of Appeals. Gonzalez v. Auto-
matic Employees Credit Union, 419 U.S. 90 (1974).
No. 74–1197. Wendell L. White, appellant, v. Richard McIntosh
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-5852. Walter E. Whitmarsh, appellant, v. Massachusetts.
Appeal from the District Court of Northern Norfolk, Massachusetts.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration of this appeal.
No. 74-6015. Nancy Jewell Cross, appellant, v. Mary Nelson
Troche Villegas et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California,
First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this appeal.
No. 74-6233. Lois M. Manion, appellant, v. Milbren, Inc. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 35, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Maine et al.
The United States has moved the Court to retain jurisdiction in this

MONDAY, MAY 12, 1975
543
case to entertain such further proceedings, enter such orders and issue
such writs as may from time to time be deemed necessary or advisable
to give proper force and effect to the decision of March 17, 1975, and
to the Court's opinion issued on that date. The motion of the United
States is granted. The parties, jointly or separately, are requestęd
within sixty days to submit for the Court's consideration a proposed
decree effectuating the March 17 decision and opinion, retaining juris-
diction over such supplemental proceedings as may be necessary or
advisable and, more specifically, making provision for appropriate
proceedings in this Court to establish the coastline of the defendant
States and the seaward boundary between the seabed lands of the
States and those of the United States. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. A-928. Ray C. Blackburn, applicant, v. City of Maple Heights.
The application for a stay of the execution and enforcement of the
judgment of the Garfield Heights Municipal Court entered on De-
cember 5, 1973, presented to Mr. Justice Stewart and by him referred
to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this application.
No. D-36. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stanley J. Bomstein.
Disbarment entered. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this matter.
No. D-37. In the Matter of Disbarment of Christopher Ker Han-
kinson. Disbarment entered. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this matter.
No. D-39. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harvey Rosenberg. Dis-
barment entered. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this matter.
No. 73-1380. Chemehuevi Tribe of Indians et al., petitioners, 2.
Federal Power Commission et al.;
No. 73-1666. Arizona Public Service Company et al., petitioners,
. Chemehuevi Tribe of Indians et al.; and
No. 73–1667. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Cheme-
huevi Tribe of Indians et al. The motion of the Chemehuevi Tribe
of Indians et al. to retax costs is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
1
No. 74-492. Ohio, petitioner, v. Terry L. Gallagher. The motion
of the Attorney General of California for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amicus curiae, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-775. City of New Orleans et al., appellants, ". Nancy
Dukes, dba Louisiana Concessions. The motion of the appellee for
appointment of counsel is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.

petition.

for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky denied.

Mr. Justice Stewart would grant certiorari. Mr. Justice Douglas

rections, Allen Ault, Commissioner;

No. 74-6350. Richard Fraizer Smith, petitioner, v. L. R. Putman,
Warden. Motions to leave to file petitions for writs of habeas corpus
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of these motions.

No. 74–5657. William Reid, petitioner, v. United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit;

Haney et al. Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of mandamus
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of these motions.

ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Today until Monday, May 19, 1975.

OPINIONS
No. 73–1723. John L. Hill, Attorney General of Texas, appellant,
2. Michael L. Stone et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Texas. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Stewart join.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 73-1531. Albert Johnson et al., petitioners, v. Mississippi et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dis-

568
MONDAY, MAY 12, 1975
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Bren-
nan joins. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 73-1977. Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, petitioner, v.
The Wilderness Society et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Douglas and
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 73–1734. W. M. Gurley, dba Gurley Oil Company, petitioner,
v. Arny Rhoden, etc. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Mississippi. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr.
Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
Adjourned until Monday, May 19, 1975, at 10 o'clock.
Х

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 19, 1975
569
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM.
No. 74–1077. Dallas County, Alabama, et al., appellants, v. F. D.
Reese et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-1128. Peter J. Pitchess, Sheriff of Los Angeles County,
petitioner, v. Charles Edward Davis. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Central District
of California with directions to vacate the orders which it entered
subsequent to the order granting a conditional writ of habeas corpus.
Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1081. Lorentz W. Hansen, appellant, v. Board of Inspectors
of Election in and for the 8th Election District of the 68th Assembly
District of New York et al. Appeal from the Appellate Division of
the Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial Department. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-1120. Robert D. Murgia, appellant, v. Massachusetts Board
of Retirement et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Massachusetts. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74–1178. Richard Collins, et al., appellants, v. Hugh D. Carey
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
580-278-75-72

570
MONDAY, MAY 19, 1975
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 74–1193. Thomas J. Sanford et al., appellants, v. Hugh Carey,
Governor of New York, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 74-1255. Marvin Miller, appellant, v. California. Appeal from
the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of California,
Orange County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 74–6249. William E. Conrad and Jean M. Conrad, appellants,
v. Meyer and Kaucher et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 74–712. United States, petitioner, v. Philip L. Bornstein et al.
The motion of respondent Page for leave to proceed further herein in
forma pauperis is denied. Snider v. All State Administrators, Inc.,
414 U.S. 685 (1974).
No. 74-884. United States, petitioner, v. Josephine M. Powell. The
motion of the respondent for leave to proceed further herein in forma
pauperis is granted. The motion of the respondent for the appoint-
ment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that Jerry J. Moberg,
Esquire, of Moses Lake, Washington, be appointed to serve as counsel
for the respondent in this case.
No. 74–1107. Francis Leo Cappaert et al., petitioners, v. United
States et al. The motion to defer consideration of the petition for writ
of certiorari is granted pending further order of this Court.
No. 74-6458. Harold George Shadd, petitioner, v. Marvin Hogan,
Warden. The application for bail presented to Mr. Justice. Douglas,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 74-1044. Massachusetts Board of Retirement et al., appellants,
v. Robert D. Murgia. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Massachusetts. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted.

No. 74-1223. United States, petitioner, v. Allegheny Airlines, Inc.
and GECC Leasing Corporation. Petitions for writs of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 74-1060. Forth Corporation et al., petitioners, v. Allegheny
Airlines, Inc. and United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 74–1083. Eugene Schaefer, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.

574
MONDAY, MAY 19, 1975
No. 74-1105. Bobby L. Forrest and Gerard E. Kiefer, dba For-
rest & Kiefer, petitioners, v. The Capital Building & Loan Association
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of

Appeals for the Fourth Circuit ; and

Garrity et al. Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of mandamus
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of these motions.

MONDAY, MAY 19, 1975
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 74-514. Howard Nicholas Johnson, petitioner, v. United
States;
No. 74-767. Showdie Chu, appellant, v. United States;
No. 74-844. Marguerite L. Oram, petitioner, v. General American
Oil Company of Texas et al.;
No. 74–1002. Taylor's Welding Service, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
David M. Bell;
No. 74-6078. Stephen William Darnold, petitioner, v. T. L. Clanon
Superintendent, California Medical Facility; and
No. 74-6232. Paul Louis Harrelson, petitioner, v. United States
et al. Petitions for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of these petitions.
No. 74-5573. James F. Ronan, petitioner, v. Clement A. Briggs
et al. Motion for leave to file petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
ASSIGNMENT ORDERS
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit on May 6, 1975, and for such addi-
tional time as may be required to complete unfinished business, pursu-
ant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on the minutes of this
Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit during the period beginning Octo-
ber 12, 1975, and ending October 17, 1975, and for such additional time
as may be required to complete unfinished business, pursuant to
28 U.S.C. § 294(a) is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court,
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Tuesday, May 27, 1975.
