7708144
MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1975
645
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-487. Clover Bottom Hospital and School, appellant, v.
Arrol Townsend et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Tennessee,
Division. Motion of the appellees for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion and appeal.
No. 74–1091. Patricia M. Farrell, appellant, v. Iowa. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Iowa. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Brennan would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argu-
ment. Mr. Justice Stewart would dismiss the appeal as untimely
docketed.
No. 74–1296. Water Transport Association et al., appellants, v.
United States et al.; and
No. 74-1297. American Waterways Operators, Inc., et al., ap-
pellants v. United States et al. Appeals from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Columbia. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
appeals.
No. 74-1380. Clarence B. Grund, appellant, v. G. B. Aldridge
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 74-6366. Virgil M. Hart and Betty R. Hart, appellants, v.
R. L. Fehseke et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Iowa. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
580-278-75-79

646
MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1975
No. 74-6313. Harry W. Maisel, appellant, v. United States and
Real Estate Board of Rochester, Inc. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Western District of New York. The appeal is
dismissed.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No.
In the Matter of the Resignation of Philip M. Car-
den. The motion of Philip M. Carden, of Nashville, Tennessee, to re-
sign as a member of the Bar of this Court is granted, and it is ordered
that his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to prac-
tice before the Bar of this Court. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this matter.
No. D-49. In the Matter of Disbarment of Loren Grant Ishler. It
is ordered that Loren Grant Ishler, of Toledo, Ohio, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, return-
able within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr. Justice.
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this matter.
No. 9, Orginial. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. The motion of the Special Master for allowance of
compensation and reimbursement of expenses is granted, and it is
ordered that such costs be borne equally by the parties to this litiga-
tion. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-389. Albemarle Paper Company et al., petitioners, v.
Joseph P. Moody et al. The motion of the petitioners for leave to file
a supplemental brief, after argument, is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas
and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion.
No. 74-850. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion and Welfare. petitioner, v. William G. Weber. The motion to dis-
pense with printing the appendix is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-891. Edgar Paul, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Edward Charles
Davis, III. The motion of Americans for Effective Law Enforcement,
Inc., et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted. Mr.
Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 74-1213. California Department of Industrial Relations, Di-
vision of Industrial Welfare, et al., petitioners, v. Homemakers Inc.,
of Los Angeles. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 74-1216. Theodore Ristaino et al., petitioners, v. James Ross,
Jr. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and Michael G.

MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1975
647
West, Esquire, of Springfield, Massachusetts, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondent in this case. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-5808. Abraham Francis, petitioner, v. C. Murray Hender-
son, Warden. The motion of the petitioner for appointment of coun-
sel is granted and Bruce S. Rogow, Esquire, of Miami, Florida, is
appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 74-6584. Daniel Jean Lipsman, petitioner, v. Alfred A.
Giardino et al. The motion to expedite consideration of the petition for
certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this motion.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 74-1329. Edward H. Hynes et al., appellants, v. The Mayor
and Council of the Borough of Oradell et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of New Jersey. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 74-1302. John T. Dunlop, Secretary of the United States
Department of Labor, et al., appellants, v. Turner Elkhorn Mining
Company et al.; and
No. 74-1316. Turner Elkhorn Mining Company et al., appellants,
v. John T. Dunlop, Secretary of the United States Department of
Labor, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Kentucky. In these cases probable jurisdiction
noted. Cases consolidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral
argument.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 74-958. United States et al., petitioners, v. Max Janis. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 74–1179. United States, petitioner, v. Mitchell Miller. Motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 74–1187. Joseph Baxter et al., petitioners, v. Nicholas A.
Palmigiano. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit granted and set for oral argu-
ment in tandem with No. 74–1194.
No. 74-1194. Jerry J. Enomoto et al., petitioners, v. John Wesley
Clutchette et al. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted and case set for oral
argument in tandem with No. 74–1187.

ASSIGNMENT ORDERS
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit during the period June 23 to June 27,
1975, and for such additional time as may be required to complete
unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered
on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit during the week of July 7, 1975, and

654
MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1975
for such additional time as may be required to complete unfinished
business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered entered on the
minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, June 16, 1975.

OPINIONS
No. 73-1820. Paul R. Philbrook, etc., appellant, v. Jean Glodgett
et al.; and
No. 74–132. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion, and Welfare, appellant, v. Jean Glodgett et al. Appeals from the
United States District Court for the District of Vermont. Judgment
affirmed. Appeal in No. 74-132 dismissed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
No. 74-124. Blue Chip Stamps et al., petitioners, v. Manor Drug
Stores, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and
Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan join.

MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1975
655
No. 74-13. Garrell S. Mullaney et al., petitioners, v. Stillman E.
Wilbur, Jr. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger joins.
No. 74-215. United States, petitioner, v. John R. Park. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell
join.
No. 73-759. Edwin Edwards, Governor of Louisiana, et al., ap-
pellants, v. Marsha B. Healy et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Louisiana to consider whether, in light of recent changes
in the state constitutional, statutory and other rules applicable, the
cause has become moot. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the decision of
this case.
Adjourned until Monday, June 16, 1975, at 10 o'clock.

MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1975

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1209. Westinghouse Electric Corporation et al., appellants,
v. County of Los Angeles et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, Second Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-1365. Roy Joyner, appellant, v. North Carolina. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-1379. Francis O. Poulson, appellant, v. Walsh-Groves et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Montana. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-1327. Democratic Executive Committee of Columbiana
County, Ohio, et al., appellants, v. Ted W. Brown, Secretary of State
of Ohio. Appeal from the United States District Court for the North-
ern District of Ohio. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio so
that a fresh order or decree may be entered from which a timely ap-
peal may be taken to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. MTM, Inc. v. Baxley, 420 U.S. - (1975).
No. 74–1342. Barbara M. Teschner, appellant, v. Chicago Title
and Trust Company et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case
for oral argument.
No. 74-1347. Ralph B. Thompson et ux., appellants, v. Property
Tax Appeal Board, State of Illinois, Department of Local Govern-
ment Affairs, County Board of Review, et al. Appeal from the
Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was

No. 74-6215. Harold Harry Woods, appellant, v. Georgia. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in
the consideration or decision of this appeal.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–6761. Jeffrey Aaron Burko, petitioner, v. Maryland. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals of Maryland for further consideration in light of
Mullaney v. Wilbur, 421 U.S. (1975). Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and petition.
No. 74-5632. Jose R. Castro, petitioner, v. Vincent J. Regan,
Superintendent, State Prison, Leesburg, N.J. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Mullaney v.
Wilbur, 421 U.S. (1975). Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion and petition.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. The joint motion for entry of supplemental decree
granted. Supplemental decree entered. Mr. Justice Douglas and
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision
of this motion.
No. A-993. Ed. Phillips & Sons Co., et al., applicants, v. Joseph
Novak, Liquor Control Commissioner of Minnesota, et al.; and
No. A-994. Griggs, Cooper & Co., Inc., applicant, v. Joseph Novak,
Liquor Control Commissioner of Minnesota, et al. The applications
for stay of enforcement of Minnesota Laws 1973, c. 664, § 2 (Minn.
St. § 340.114). presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun and by him referred
to the Court, are denied. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of these applications.
No. D-41. In the Matter of Disbarment of George J. Siegel. Dis-
barment entered. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this matter.
No. D-44. In the Matter of Disbarment of Edward LeRoy Morgan.
Disbarment entered. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
took no part in the consideration or decision of this matter.

MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1975
659
No. 73–62. Hubert Wheeler et al., petitioners, v. Anna Barrera
et al. The motion of the petitioners for modification of the judgment
is granted, and the last paragraph of this Court's judgment dated
June 10, 1974, is hereby modified to read:
"On Consideration Whereof, it is ordered and adjudged by this
Court that the judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit in this cause be, and the same is hereby, affirmed,
with directions that the case be remanded to the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Western District of Missouri for further action
consistent with the opinion and judgment of this Court." Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 73–1288. Alfred Dunhill of London, Inc., petitioner, v. The
Republic of Cuba et al. This case is restored to the calendar for re-
argument. In addition to other questions presented by this case, coun-
sel are requested to brief and discuss during oral argument: Should
this Court's holding in Banco Nacional de Cuba v. Sabbatino, 376
U.S. 398, be reconsidered?
No. 74-773. Scott Hudgens, petitioner, v. National Labor Rela-
tions Board et al. The motion of respondents for additional time for
oral argument is granted and fifteen additional minutes are allotted
for that purpose. The petitioner is allotted fifteen additional minutes
for oral argument. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this motion.
No. 74-1141. United States, petitioner, v. Bobby Gene Gaddis and
Billy Sunday Birt. The motion of for appointment of counsel is grant-
ed and Tommy Day Wilcox, Esquire, of Macon, Georgia, is appointed
to serve as counsel for the respondents in this case. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-1222. Charles L. Wolff, Jr., Warden, petitioner, v. David
L. Rice. The application of the respondent for bail pending disposi-
tion of the petition for writ of certiorari, presented to Mr. Justice
Blackmun and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this ap-
plication.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

Moss et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted. Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.
No. 74-1243. Alvin A. Beckwith, Jr.. petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
B
1

660
MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1975
for the District of Columbia Circuit granted. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 74-6293. Philip J. Goldberg, petitioner, v. United States.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit granted, limited to Question 8 presented by the petition which
reads as follows:
"Whether 18 U.S.C. § 3500. the Jencks Act, contains an 'attorney's
work product exception'; and whether a Government attorney's notes
of conversations with the key Government witness, to whom the
prosecutors read back their notes from time to time where the wit-
ness corrected same, which notes were prepared 'only after lengthy
conversations had occurred and a mutual understanding of the factual
situation' had been reached, if not compellable under the Jencks Act,
are compellable under the doctrine of Brady v. Maryland." Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion
and petition.
CERTIORARI DENIED

of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 74-6453. James Barksdale, petitioner, v. Daniel J. Ryan,
Judge of the Circuit Court of Cook County, Chicago, Illinois et al.
Petition for writ for certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 74-6459. Ernie Ree Ainsworth, petitioner, v. Mississippi.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this petition.
No. 74-6470. Eleanor M. Hemstreet, petitioner, v. State Personnel
Board. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia, Second Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

No. 74-6481. Stuart E. Hirsch, petitioner, v. Maryland State Bar
Association, Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals
of Maryland denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.
No. 74-6517. Royal Gene Chambler, petitioner, v. W. J. Estelle,
Jr., Director, Texas Department of Corrections. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.
No. 74-6560. Don Wheeler, Sr., petitioner, v. Tennessee. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle
Division denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the considera-
tion of this petition.
No. 74-294. Mitchell Watson et al., petitioners, v. Kenlick Coal
Company, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 74-1045. John E. Moss et al., petitioners, v. Federal Power
Commission. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied. The Chief
Justice and Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari. Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this petition.
No. 74-1063. Carl R. Carter et al., petitioners, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 74-1094. Herman L. Womack and Potomac News Company,
petitioners, v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-
cuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom
Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting state-
ment by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 74-1103. W. J. Estelle, Jr., Director, Texas Department of
Corrections, petitioner. v. Billy Lee Johnson. Motion of respondent
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit denied. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice White would grant
certiorari.
No. 74-1115. Marvin Miller et al., petitioners, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-

Carolina denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice White would

No. 74–1234. Manuel Glenn Abascal, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall would grant certiorari, vacate judgment and remand case
to the Court of Appeals for consideration of the question of mootness.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.
No. 74-1237. Richard E. Brown et al., petitioners. v. United
States et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for Third Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would
grant certiorari. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this petition.

singer, Secretary of Defense. Motion of Americans for Middle East.
Neutrality for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant
certiorari.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit on June 6, 1975, and
for such additional time as may be required to complete unfinished
business, pursuant to 28. U.S.C. § 94 (a) is ordered entered on the
minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. 295.

No. 74-362. Intercounty Construction Corporation et al., peti-
tioners, v. Noah C. A. Walter, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 74–157. United Housing Foundation, Inc., et al., petitioners,
2. Milton Forman et al.; and
No. 74-647. State of New York and the New York State Housing
Finance Agency, petitioners, v. Milten Forman et al. On Writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceeding in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice.

MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1975
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice White

No. 73-1309. Jeffrey Cole Bigelow, appellant, e. Virginia. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Virginia. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with
whom Mr. Justice White joins.
No. 74–5116. Jack Roland Murphy, petitioner. v. Florida. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 74-70. Lewis H. Goldfarb et ux., petitioners, v. Virginia State
Bar et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals with orders to remand to the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Virginia for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

TUESDAY, JUNE 17, 1975
677
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell,
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
OPINIONS
No. 73-1933. United States, appellant, v. Citizens and Southern
National Bank et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice White join.
No. 74-452. Twentieth Century Music Corporation et al., peti-
tioners, v. George Aiken. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring
in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins.
No. 73-1908. Stewart S. Cort et al., petitioners, v. Richard A. Ash,
etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 73-6336. George Herman Rogers, petitioner, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins.
No. 74-415. Francis A. Rondeau, petitioner, v. Mosinee Paper
Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals with directions to reinstate the
judgment of the United States District Court for the Western District
of Wisconsin. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas
joins. Mr. Justice Marshall dissents.
Adjourned until Monday, June 23, 1975, at 10 o'clock.
Х
580-278-75-82

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1975
679
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1413. Elmer B. Staats, Comptroller-General of the United
States, et al., appellants, v. American Civil Liberties Union, Inc., et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Columbia. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Columbia with directions
to dismiss the cause as moot. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-872. National Society of Professional Engineers, appellant,
v. United States. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Columbia. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the District of Columbia for
further consideration in light of Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421
U.S. (1975). Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
1
No. 74-1169. David Rogers et al., appellants, v. Inmates' Council-
matic Voice et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Ohio. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio
so that a fresh order or decree may be entered from which a timely
appeal may be taken to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 74-1227. Gisela Ellis and Ernest Sturm, appellants, v. Cali-
fornia. Appeal from the Appellate Department of the Superior Court
of California, County of Santa Barbara. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-1467. William C. Haas & Co., Inc., appellant, v. Russian
Hill Improvement Association et al. Appeal from the Court of Ap-
peal of California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
580-278-75--83

680
MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1975
No. 74-6469. In re the District Court of the Fifth Judicial District
of Montana, etc., et al. (Richard Mitchell et ux., Real Parties in
Interest), appellants, v. Montana ex rel. Allen LeMieux, County At-
torney, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Montana. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74–1375. Dennis M. Montgomery, appellant, v. William A.
Douglas et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Colorado. Judgment affirmed.
No. 74-1404. Ralph Pressman, appellant, v. New York State et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would dismiss
the appeal for want of jurisdiction.
No. 74–1458. Dudley Clark et al., appellants, v. J. Elbert Peters
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Dallas County, Ala. v. Reese,
421 U.S. (1975).
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-1162. James Bob Impson, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of United States v. Hale, U.S. — (1975).
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
·
No. 74-5092. Cecil Grafton Rose, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of United States v. Hale, — U.S. (1975). Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
--
-
No. 74-6118. Douglas Watts, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Upon representation of the
Solicitor General set forth in his brief for the United States filed May
2, 1975, judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Georgia to permit the Gov-
ernment to dismiss charges against the petitioner. Dissenting opinion

MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1975
681
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger with whom Mr. Justice White and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist join. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion and petition.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No.
In the Matter of Resignation of Richard M. Nixon.
The motion of Richard M. Nixon, of San Clemente, California, to
resign as a member of the Bar of this Court is granted, and it is
ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted
to practice before the Bar of this Court. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this
matter.
No. . Henry G. Fuentes, applicant, v. Workers' Compensa-
tion Appeals Board of California et al. The motion to dispense with
printing the petition for writ of certiorari is denied. Snider v. All State
Administrators, Inc., 414 U.S. 685 (1974).
No. 73–1808. James Burnett McKay Laing, petitioner, v. United
States et al.; and
No. 74-75. United States et al., petitioners, v. Elizabeth Jane Hall;
and
No. 73-7031. Jesse Thurman Fowler, petitioner, v. North Carolina.
These cases are restored to the calendar for reargument.
No. 74-858. Hugh L. Carey, Governor of the State of New York,
et al., appellants, v. Bert Randolph Sugar and Wrestling Revue, Inc.;
and
No. 74-859. Curtis Circulation Company and Continental Cas-
ualty Company, appellants, v. Bert Randolph Sugar and Wrestling
Revue, Inc. The motion of appellants for addititonal time for oral
argument is granted and ten additional minutes are allotted for that
purpose. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this motion.
No. 74-940. Colorado River Water Conservation District et al.,
petitioners, v. United States; and
No. 74–949. Mary Akin et al., petitioners, v. United States. The
motion of petitioners for divided argument is granted. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of his motion.
No. 74–1287. Robert Weinstein et al., petitioners, v. Howard E.
Bradford et al. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and
Howard Lesnick, Esquire, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, is appointed
to serve as counsel for the respondents in this case. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 74-1366. Robert Schaefer et al., petitioners, v. First National
Bank of Lincolnwood et al.; and
1

682
MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1975
No. 74-1407. Rodman & Renshaw, petitioner, v. Robert Schaefer
et al.; and
No. 74-1427. Reuben L. Anderson-Cherne, Inc., appellant, v. The
Commissioner of Revenue of the State of Minnesota. The Solicitor
General is invited to file briefs in these cases expressing the views
of the United States.

No. 74-1274. Abbott Laboratories et al., petitioners, v. Portland
Retail Druggists Association, Inc., etc. Motion of American Hospital
Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit granted. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion and petition.
No. 74-1393. Thomas E. Singleton, etc., petitioner, v. George J. L.
Wulff, Jr., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted limited to Questions
1 and 2 presented by the petition which read as follows:
"1. Whether there is a logical nexus between the status of respond-
ent-physicians and the claims they seek to have adjudicated sufficient
to confer standing on them to challenge the constitutionality of Section
208.152, RSMo Supp. 1973.

MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1975
683
"2. Whether the Court of Appeals acted in excess of its jurisdiction
when it proceeded to determine on the merits the constitutionality of
Section 208.152, RSMo Supp. 1973.”
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.
No. 74-1435. The Environmental Protection Agency et al., peti-
tioners, v. California ex rel. State Water Resources Control Board.
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Case set for oral argument in
tandem with No. 74-200 - Hancock v. Train.

OPINIONS
Lacovara.
No. 73-1942. Richard Erznoznik, etc., appellant, v. City of Jack-
sonville. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, First
District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the District Court
of Appeal of Florida, First District, for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist
joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White.
No. 74–634. United States, petitioner, v. Robert Lee Nobles. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by Justice White concur-
ring in the judgment and in parts II, III, and V of the Court's
opinion, with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 73-1888. United States, petitioner, v. Alaska. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting statement by Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-364. United States, petitioner, v. William G. Hale. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr Justice
Marshall. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the
judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas concurring in the judg-
ment. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in the judgment.
Mr. Justice Blackmun concurs in the result.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 74-726. Robert Sheldon, Superintendent, Rusk State Hospital,
appellant, v. Perry Wayne Reynolds; and
No. 74-5743. Perry Wayne Reynolds, appellant, v. Robert Sheldon,
Superintendent. Rusk State Hospital. Appeals from the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Texas. The motions of
Perry Wayne Reynolds for leave to proceed in forma pauperis are
granted. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Texas for further con-
sideration in light of O'Connor v. Donaldson, 422 U.S. (1975).
No. 74-1181. Emanuel Mazer et al., appellants, v. Caspar W. Wein-
berger, Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare, et al.; and
No. 74-5538. Paul Kohr etc., appellant, v. Caspar W. Weinberger,
Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare, et al. Appeals from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.
Motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis in No. 74–
5538, granted. Judgments vacated and cases remanded to the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania to con-
sider its jurisdiction in light of Weinberger v. Salfi, 422 U.S.
(1975). Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice Marshall joins.
No. 74-6102. James C. Hagler and Shirley Hagler, his wife,
appellants, v. Marcellus K. Snow, District Judge, etc. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Utah. Motion of appellants for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Supreme Court of Utah for further consideration in light of
North Georgia Finishing, Inc. v. Di-Chem, Inc., 419 U.S. 601 (1975).

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 74–730. John C. Roemer, III, et al., appellants, v. Board of
Public Works of Maryland et al. The motion of the appellees for ad-
ditional time for oral argument is granted and fifteen additional
minutes are allotted for that purpose. The appellants are allotted fif-
teen additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 74–1179. United States, petitioner, v. Mitchell Miller. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and Denver Lee Ram-
pey, Jr., Esquire. of Warner Robins, Georgia, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondent in this case.

704
MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1975
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 74-1137. Abe Lavine, etc., appellant, v. Ronald Milne et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of New York. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 74–6212. Gregory Norton, Jr., etc., appellant, v. Caspar W.
Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of Maryland.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case
further consideration of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to
the hearing of the case on the merits. See Weinberger v. Salfi, No. 74–
214, n. 8 (June 26, 1975).
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73–861. East Carroll Parish School Board and East Carroll
Parish Police Jury, petitioners, v. Stewart Marshall. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit granted.
No. 74-520. Ernest L. Montanye, Former Superintendent, Attica
Correctional Facility et al., petitioners, v. Rodney R. Haymes. Motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit granted.
No. 74-1055. W. T. Stone, Warden, petitioner, v. Lloyd Charles
Powell. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. In addition to those questions
presented by the petition, counsel are requested to brief and argue the
following question:
"Whether, in light of the fact that the District Court found that the
Henderson, Nevada police officer had probable cause to arrest respond-
ent for violation of an ordinance which at the time of the arrest had
not been authoritatively determined to be unconstitutional, respond-
ent's claim that the gun discovered as a result of a search incident to
that arrest violated his rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth
Amendments to the United States Constitution is one cognizable under
28 U.S.C. § 2254."
No. 74–1222. Charles L. Wolff, Jr., Warden, petitioner, v. David
L. Rice. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted. In addition to those questions
presented by the petition, counsel are requested to brief and argue the
following question:
>

MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1975
705
"Whether the constitutional validity of the entry and search of
respondent's premises by Omaha police officers under the circum-
stances of this case is a question properly cognizable under 28 U.S.C.
§ 2254.
CERTIORARI DENIED

MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1975
707
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision
of the cases in which orders or judgments in unargued cases are this
day announced.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit from October 20, 1975, to Octo-
ber 24, 1975, and for such additional time as may be required to com-
plete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a) is ordered
entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

OPINIONS
Keeffe.
No. 74-337. Frank Doran, etc., appellant, v. Salem Inn, Inc., et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. Appeal dismissed. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is granted. Judg-
ment reversed as to respondent M & L and affirmed as to respondents
Salem and Tim-Rob and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part in the
Court's opinion.
No. 73-6848. John Lee Bowen, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting
statement by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Stewart dissents.
No. 74–114. United States, petitioner, v. Felix Humberto Brignoni-
Ponce. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the judgment with
whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins in this case and in No. 73–2050,
post. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice.
White with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins concurring in the judg-
ment in this case and in No. 73–2050, post.

MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1975
711
No. 73–2050. United States, petitioner, v. Luis Antonio Ortiz. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Concur-
ring opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger concurring in the judgment with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun
joins in this case and in No. 74-114, ante. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins concurring in the
judgment in this case and in No. 74–114, ante.
No. 73-5772. Anthony Pasquall Faretta, petitioner, v. California.
On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Second
Appellate District. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeal of California. Second Appellate District, for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 73–6587. Clifford Herring, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, Sec-
ond Judicial Department. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, Second
Judicial Department, for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
No. 73–1462. Mark White et al., appellants, v. Diana Regester et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western Dis-
trict of Texas. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Western District of Texas for recon-
sideration in light of the recent Texas reapportionment legislation
and for dismissal if the case is or becomes moot. Opinion per curiam
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Douglas took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 74-456. John Hill, Attorney General of Texas, et al., appellants,
v. Printing Industries of the Gulf Coast et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of Texas. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for
the Southern District of Texas for reconsideration in light of the
new legislation and for dismissal if the case is or becomes moot. Opin-
ion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

712
MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1975
The Chief Justice said:
"All cases submitted and all business before the Court at this term
in readiness for disposition having been disposed of,
"It is ordered by this Court that all cases on the docket be, and
they are hereby, continued to the next term."
Adjourned to the time and place appointed by law.
